I loved playing around with this camera, it was so user friendly and I found myself quickly switching the dial to M and shooting in fully manual!I haven't really used the new touch screen feature for changing settings etc yet but I have used it for flicking through my shots in review mode, this makes it much faster than the old way of using the dial and left/right buttons however; I'm not a big touch screen fan, on any device as I hate all the finer marks left behind, but that's just my own personal peeve and one which may not bother others?In a nutshell (I'll leave the real technical reviews to those more technically minded than I) I would highly recommend the Canon T4i as an upgrade from your previous T2i/T3/T3i or even your 30D - 60D..... the new Digic 5 image processor is well worth making the purchase on its own, without all the other added features that this camera has.  You will instantly see the difference in your images, even when shooting at a much higher ISO and I would imagine that even when it comes to printing, an image shot at 3200 / 6400 ISO would still make for a fantastic print to hang on any wall!!I certainly don't feel like I have made a step backwards from the "D" series by purchasing this nifty little Rebel and I think you will be as pleased with it as I am.

Reviews.Title: Get the STM lens if you use Video
Reviews.Author: J. O. Vancleave
Reviews.Content: Be warned that the regular lenses are worthless for video - you will hear them loudly stuttering to find focus even in noisy settings.Get the STM lenses - the 50mm is almost silent, but the 18-135mm is completely silent and much faster in focusing than the kit lens.  Also a very nice range if you do not want to carry more lenses.

Reviews.Title: Having a great time
Reviews.Author: William L. Chambers "Bios Element"
Reviews.Content: I just got the camera yesterday, however so far it's working like a charm. You actually have to work at it to take bad shots and while others have complained about it's low-light shooting, I'm absolutely shocked at how good a shot I can get at near pitch-black conditions.Regarding the recall, I apparently lucked out as this camera is not affected. So while others have been unlucky, Your results may vary.

Reviews.Title: Excellent but not a no-brainer
Reviews.Author: FreeAtLast
Reviews.Content: I am astonished at how much more this camera provides than the lower-priced digital cameras I've owned in the past -- but, for this still-a-tyro photographer, it provides its challenges.Yes, you can use the camera as a point-and-shoot in auto mode, but why pay all this money to use it as a fully automatic camera?  The fun . . . and the challenge . . . is to play with aperture, shutter speed, and ISO.  But, learning how to do so is, simultaneously, a challenge, a process, and where the fun and results are.The camera gives you several ways to do virtually anything -- and that can get confusing.  Where do I find this?  What is the point of my doing this or that?  How do I find out?My first and best suggestion is an excellent course from the Great Courses ([...]) called "Fundamentals of Photography" by National Geographic photograpgher Joel Santore. It is NOT a course in the Canon Rebel T4i, but it IS a course that will explain aperture, shutter speed, depth of field, composition, and a lot about digital cameras.  Whatever he covers is doable with the Rebel T4i.  And, he'll have you WANTING to do it.  The only question is, "How?"  The course is frequently on sale and should be bought only when it is on sale since the "regular" price is considerably higher and unnecessary.  On sale, the course goes for around $60.That's where the second reference comes in, Canon EOS Rebel T4i/650D For Dummies by Julie Adair King.  You can get it for about $16 from Amazon.Sartore's course will provide knowledge, motivation, and a clear idea of what you might try.  The King book will help you fill in the gaps on how, specifically, do you do it with the Canon.Some random notes:o  Sartore's course is, IMHO, the best by far of the Great Course offerings (although some of the music courses by Robert Greenberg are pretty good).  He gives "homework" assignments to help develop you as a photographer.  They're worth actually doing!o  Those whose prior experience with lower-priced digital cameras had them disappointed because of the slow focusing and shooting speeds, can rest easy.  This camera focuses quickly and its burst speed is remarkable, allowing you to take a barrage of pictures in very rapid order.  Those people who you find attractive but not photogenic will now take a good picture because, by taking several pictures rapidly, you'll catch those micro expressions which account for their attractiveness.  (Everyone is as photogenic if you take enough pictures of them.  And, since there is no cost to taking lots of pictures, why not?)o  Aperture, the size of the opening through which a picture is taken, determines the depth of field (i.e., whether the background is clear or not).  Learn to use it to take pictures that blur the background when the subject is more important and to provide 3-D effects.  (The more the background is blurred, the more the subject seems to leap off the page ... or canvas if you have the picture printed out on canvas and blown up.)o  Shutter speed -- the faster the shutter speed, the more an action is frozen rather than blurred.  At the higher speeds, a moving fan will appear to be a picture of a stopped fan or a kicked football will appear frozen in the air.  At the lower speeds, more light is admitted and a tripod may be necessary.o  ISO speed.  With modern cameras, one can shoot at night without a flash if the ISO speed is set high enough.  The downside?  The shots may appear grainier.And there is the photographer's trio -- smaller apertures and faster shutter speeds, which are sometimes desired, admit less light.  So, one has to decide whether to use a flash or a higher ISO (film or memory sensitivity to light).  Or, if one doesn't use fully manual mode, one can pick a setting that allows you to take control of any one of the Big 3 and allow the camera to take care of the other 2 -- which is, in fact, what I usually opt to do.==================================================================The camera is highly capable and flexible.  Go with a high speed, high capacity memory card to avoid handcuffing it.  Then, get out of automatic mode and explore it.NOTE:  I know.  I know.  This review is useless for those who know photography and cameras well.  But, you're not my audience. I'm writing for those who want to take the next step to assist in their finding an approach to learning more about this camera.I haven't said a lot about the camera itself, per se, other than that it's capable and flexible.  But, others have covered its capabilities far better than I can.  I'm just telling the other tyros who are considering stepping up that the water is fine and where to get their swimming lessons.I feared that I had bought too much camera but have been glad to find that the camera is like Excel.  You can use it immediately and get some fine results.  But, when ready, you can use it at far deeper levels and will find that whatever you want to do with it you can do with it . . . if you dig a little deeper to learn more of its capabilities.  You won't outgrow it, but you can certainly grow as a photographer with it.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera for the money
Reviews.Author: maciej zelek
Reviews.Content: Ive been a canon user for the last few years.  I cut my teeth on the canon xti that I got as a handy down camera and felt that I get everything I could get out of it, so it was time for an upgrade.I chose this camera because its effectively a D60 with a lower price, smaller body and newer processor with a bunch of new added features.You get all the performance that you would expect from canons higher end camera but in a smaller form factor and lower price.  Also the touch screen is fantastic for quickly switching camera functions and Id take the touch screen over multiple dials and a top lcd plate any day.  The inclusion of the movie mode right on the on/off switch seems like a small feature but it gives you so much more flexibility as you can now shoot video in full manual and no longer requires you to spin the mode dial half way across the planet just to shoot a video.  The photo quality is really quite excellent and Im blown away at the amount of detail preserved in the shots.  Also one other really quite cool feature is that you can use the internal flash as a trigger for a external flash gun, something to keep in mind if you already own a flash with a slave function.All that being said the camera does have some draw backs.  The image quality is amazing but its no better than the t2i and t3i, so if you already own one of those cameras then their really is no point in upgrading.  Also unless you have one of their new stm lenses the autofocus in live mode is really quite abysmal and not at all usable for video recording, be prepared for a lot of manual focusing.  Which leads me to my next point, the view finder is quite dim and not really well suited for manual focus but that is alleviated somewhat by the zoom function in live view.All my complaints though are quite nit picky and really wont affect your shooting on a day to day basis.  And over all you're going to enjoy this camera wether its your first DSLR or your upgrading from some older kit.5 stars amazing camera and will hold me over till I win the loto and can afford a 1Dc.

Reviews.Title: Just OMG kind of product
Reviews.Author: Yelena Burkut "mom of two"
Reviews.Content: Absolutely love this product. And does so many things. Flip screen is great for vlogging, quality is amazing. Do make sure to buy 18-135 mm Lens. The price difference is totally worth it. I was hesitant, especially since I was already spending so much money, but it like buying a lens that would wonders vs a lens that would just do ok job. Also separately this lens would cost a lot more

Reviews.Title: Upgraded from a 40D. Very Surprised and very Happy!
Reviews.Author: Consumer "flymach1"
Reviews.Content: WOW! I upgraded from a Canon 40D and I expected to like the newer functions and being able to shoot video. I did not expect to be blown away, just glad to have some new features. Within about a minute of turning the camera and playing around with it I was actually blown away by the ease of shooting and the clarity of the handheld shots in low lighting. With the 18-135 STM lens, I didn't expect great low light ability because it isn't a fast 2.8 lens. To test it I took some photos of fish in my aquarium with the tank lights off and only one light on the other side of the room. I couldn't believe how well they turned out. The image stabilization worked very well and the image was sharp for a handheld shot as I expected. What really got me was the color it captured. It was catching the colors I feel like I see in the full light. I couldn't even see the color very well at all with my eyes, but the camera was working it's magic and pulling them out - faithful to the actual color of the fish and corals. I didn't expect that at all. I actually said "WOW!" when I saw the first image. I took multiple shots zoomed in and they all looked great. I tried out the flash and think there is a little more height of this pop up flash compared to the one on the 40D. I was taking pictures of the fish behind the glass of the aquarium and I was getting great lighting without a big bright flash showing up in the picture. Whatever the combination of zoom, flash height, flash coverage, whatever, it really gave me great results.I didn't expect to be able to have a shallow depth of field with this lens, but I could zoom in and focus on the keys on my keyboard and have items 4 inches behind it blurry with a booka like effect. The focus was very defined where I wanted it.The touch screen works beautifully for me. I really like the ability to have the live view mode up when shooting, have the angle I want to shoot at without having to crank my neck around to see in the viewfinder, view playback on it and pinch to zoom just like on an iPhone, and touch the area I want the camera to focus on. The picture is so much clearer on this display than it was on the screen of the 40D.I've only spent about 30 minutes with this camera and lens combo and I know I will love it. I actually decided to quit playing around with it and write this review because I was so happy with it and wanted to recommend it to others.If you are thinking about getting the body only, I highly recommend getting the 18-135 STM lens. The lens is over $500 by itself. Bundled with the body, it is a great deal for about a hundred bucks more than the body alone.

Reviews.Title: Great Entry Level dSLR
Reviews.Author: Neil
Reviews.Content: I upgraded to the T4i from my 2007 xTi because I wanted to take advantage of the "newest" Rebel sensor and ability to shoot ISO 800 and 1600 with minimal noise (I was capped to ISO 400 on the xTi). I've used the entry level Sonys and Nikons and feel that although they may get better reviews than the Canons on certain Websites, I have Canon lenses and flashes and the Canon Rebels offer a perfect balance of ergonomics, control and image quality. Canon is a lot like GE - they may not be best in class in everything but you're going to be hard pressed to find a market that GE is outside the top 3. Canon does everything on their cameras very good to excellent (e.g. build, reliability, features, image quality, etc.) - when you do that across the board, you get an outstanding product. One thing I love about the T4i (and previous Rebels) is that you get direct button access to the most common settings (e.g. ISO, white balance, focus area). I can't believe how many cameras (even the more advanced Canon 60D) bury some of these settings in the menus. Additionally, the new T4i touch screen is cool and well implemented (although totally unnecessary). One other cool new feature is the T4i recognizes the lens you are using and corrects two lens aberrations automatically (peripheral and chromatic). I know you can do that yourself in post-production and I'm not even sure how effective it is but I assume it's doing some good!The T4i does everything extremely well except for the following:Live view (i.e. using the viewfinder to shoot) - this is terrible - it takes forever to focus, especially indoors. However, I rarely ever use live view - the only time I would ever use live view instead of the viewfinder is when I want a creative angle (e.g. holding the camera above my head or putting it on the ground). This represents about 1 of every 500 photos I take. Similarly, as others mentioned, the focusing during video is loud. You can "fix" this by buying a lens tailored toward video or by focusing on something before starting your video and then deactivating the servo autofocus. Of course you will only focus on what you originally focused on before recording the video. Obviously this only works if you film something that remains in one focus plane. And you remove the much heralded option of focusing on one thing and then switching focus to another thing mid-video.The new handheld night scene and HDR backlight scenes are awesome, but when you move to those modes on the dial you are forced to shoot in green box (i.e. automatic) mode. For those shooters experienced enough to recognize when they need to activate those two new modes it is disappointing to be forced into automatic mode - auto ISO, auto focusing point, auto WB. Additionally, Canon put these two new modes on the opposite side of the dial as the M and AV modes. I shoot in M and AV virtually 100% of the time - the exception is when I want to shoot the new HDR or handheld night modes. Those two new modes are about 12 clicks away from M and AV on the dial - not only is it annoying and time consuming to move the 12 clicks to the new modes, but I'm sure I'm putting wear and tear on the dial. Either Canon didn't expect people to use these modes as often as others (e.g. macro, sports, landscape) or the Rebel user base primarily shoots in the pre-set modes, making the M and AV shooters like me the minority.Lastly, I think I read that when you shoot Auto ISO (something I don't do) and use flash, the ISO won't drop below 400. For those who know a little about photography, this means it will be very hard for use to use fill-flash outdoors - if you're outside shooting ISO 400, most of the time you will be above 1/250.As you can see, my criticisms of the camera (mentioned above) are for very minor items. I love everything about the camera other than the nitpicks cited above - thus the 5 star rating! Buy with confidence.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, lots more features than the t3i, IQ is excellent
Reviews.Author: Defector "keep travelling"
Reviews.Content: I have been working with this camera for a month now and just enjoy it so much.I learned the old way with 35mm slr's, hasselblad's, mamiya etc but find the versatility of this new dslr fantastic.Shooting in raw  with a 50mm 1.4, 85mm 1.8 and the 18-135 kit lens is a pleasure, simple and intuitive.The kit lens is not very fast and bokeh not great but for video work it's just dandy, if that is your thing and quiet too.Image quality is excellent, I have been using Aperture for post and the only faults I find are in my own technique which I can correct.If you already have a T3i wait and see what comes next, if you were looking at upgrading from a T2i or wanted this as a backup camera for a more expensive setup I don't think you can go wrong.Get yourself a battery grip, tripod and some good quality ND filters and you can't go wrong.There is plenty of info around on the web for the best settings and that is personal preference.It's a great starter camera and at the high end of the crop sensors, don't listen to the gear heads it's what you do with it that counts.Remember the best camera is the one you have with you, unless your an instagram nut, adding a post filter to a picture of a bag of chips does not make it cool, it's still an uninteresting pic of a bag of chips ;)Have fun!

Reviews.Title: Minor update to older T1i, T2i,  T3i  Cameras
Reviews.Author: Leslie E. Sparks
Reviews.Content: I purchased this to replace my T1i Canon camera that didn't survive a fall and dunking in a creek. If I hadn't fallen, I would not have updated. The T4i sensor is at best a minor upgrade from the sensor used in all the Txi line (including my T1i). It has slightly more MPs than my T1i (18 vs 15+) so the increase in resolution doesn't justify an upgrade. Dynamic range and noise control as rated by DX0 are also basically the same for the entire Txi line. (Note that I do see improved noise handing with the T4i compared to the T1i ISO 1600 is useful especially with Lightroom 4) This means that the upgrade from the T1i to the T4i does not provide improved image quality for still photographs. So if you own an early Canon Rebel Txi you will get more image quality improvement by investing in a new lens than by investing in a new camera.That being said the T4i does provide improvements in handling and for movies. The articulated LCD is a joy to use. It's something that you have to use to appreciate and wonder how you got along without it.Auto focus is quicker and seems to be more accurate in many situations. With my T1i the auto focus would often hunt for focus--I don't see this with the T4i.For those interested in video the big advance is continuous auto focus when in video mode. This usually works quite well. However, there are times when the auto focus tries to make small adjustments and the focus changes slightly. Also the auto focus sometimes is slow to react when in video mode. The big draw back to continuous focus is that the mike picks up the noise of the focus motor. For my use this is no big deal because I replace the in camera sound track. Canon's new lenses for this camera a supposed to be overcome this issue.If you're thinking that this camera provides a single camera solution to your desire for video and stills you need to carefully consider your needs. It's a very good serious still camera. And if used properly it's also a very good serious video camera. But if you're looking for a video camera to take video of your kids soccer games and general family video, you might be better off with a video camcorder. The T4i is heavier than a camcorder--especially with a moderate to long zoom lens. You don't have power zoom, so you won't be able to zoom in on your kid when he scores the wining goal with the same ease that you can with power zoom. But if you want shallow depth of field effects and other pro video effects, then the T4i will produce for you.In summary, this is a very good DSLR at a good price. The image quality is excellent and can produce at least 16x20" prints (Biggest that my printer can provide.) I love the way the camera handles it's better than by older T1i. I like the video and find that I use it more often than I thought. But I still use my camcorder most of the time for video.If you've invested in Canon and have a small to large collection of high quality Canon lenses, then you should look at this to see if the improved video and handling justify the investment in a new body. If you're looking at investing in your first DSLR you should consider the T4i, but you should also look an the Nikon and Sony offerings. Nikon and Sony offer cameras with higher resolution and better dynamic range and noise handling. The video capabilities of the T4i are superior to the video capabilities of similar Nikon and Sony cameras. So consider you needs carefully and then review all the cameras offered. Luckily for us all the cameras are good enough so you should be happy with what you select.

Reviews.Title: 2nd time around for me . . .Exactly what I want!!
Reviews.Author: Luke Wood
Reviews.Content: Being a casual photography enthusiast, for me the Rebel level systems fit my need and budget just right . . .i have stuck with Canon cameras for over 45 years . . .I had a T2i when they came out . . .loved the camera for photos . . .hated the video without tilt screen and auto focus . . .Sold the whole kit and went to a p&s; for a few years.  Enter the T4i with all of my complaints answered I bought everything back that I had sold . . . The 18-35 STM and 40mm STM lenses are great for video and general walk-around use plus I went for the 55-250 IS lens (I also had before) $150 discount deal available at time of purchase and bought another 10-22 USM to replace the one I sold . . .  Auto focus video is a little slow but once you get used to shooting it is very workable . . . Unsatisfactory focus times easily edited around in iMovie or similar, etc.  I only use the live view for still images to frame a scene and shoot using the viewfinder.  All of the pre-programmed modes work wonderfully as advertised and the touch screen is outstanding once you get used to it for using the TV, AV, or M creative zones . . .In every mode, changing from single shot to continuos shooting, ISO settings and just about every other setting you would ever change in the middle of a shoot is available on the fly as though you were using a smart phone . . .i was considering getting a 60d but professional reviews were a toss up between the two bodies and the the touch screen was the deal breaker for me . . .A few reviewers have mentioned that the T4i doesn't have a "Bulb" setting but it does so you  the easily get around the 30 second shutter max by choosing the "M" setting and dialing to the bulb selection . . .previous Rebels had the bulb setting on the settings dial as an individual selection.  Other reviewer complaints have also been answered by downloading the User Manual PDF and using the great search tool it contains!I have posted a couple of shots taken the day I received my camera . . . Please feel free to ask any questions you may have!

Reviews.Title: new canon T4i review
Reviews.Author: mr nobody
Reviews.Content: Had this new T4i for a few weeks now and it is still offering me new things to discover. This is my first DSLR so I don't have others in my experience to compare it to. Having said that - Most of the dial options are the same, it seems as on my old powershot. Some of those options give slightly different results than what I expected but in a new and improved sort of way. The lens is the most interesting aspect. It is meant to be silent while focusing and zooming while shooting video.  It was hard to get used to not having the distance marked on the lens but I have learned how to manual focus using the viewfinder. Jpgs at mid to telephoto range are a bit murky and show more aliasing than I expected. But that could be my inexperience. The RAW images are great though. I have not done the movies yet. Will update as I go along.UPDATE: Hi all I wanted to check back in a tell you about how it's going with the T4i. I still love it and am learning all sorts of new techniques with it. Great first DSLR. The one thing I would say that is a bit of shock is the dust and dirt issue. The camera gets dirt in it very easily. Granted I shoot outside with it but I was not prepared for the amount of dirt that gets in the camera. The seal between the lens and the body is not absolute. This could be just my camera and not all T4is. It may be the nature of the beast. I have ordered some cleaning supplies and seen a few tuts on cleaning so it is really no big deal, just something to be aware of for first time DSLRers; Mind that dust!There is kickstarter project that addressses this issue the "dust donut" gasket sort of thing. I have already given to this project.Here's a link.[...]

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera
Reviews.Author: D. J. K. Meadowcroft
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing camera, I love the quality of the pictures it takes.  If you were wondering which lens to buy it with, if you can afford the extra $$ go for the 18-135mm, it is good quality and you will appreciate the extra zoom.  Ignore the negative reviews about the decomposing grip as amazon has stopped shipping those.  I have had the camera about 2 weeks, and so far very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Great camera after it returned from immediate recall
Reviews.Author: Patrick Neis "Power User"
Reviews.Content: When I purchased the camera I was very impressed with the quality of the camera, and enjoyed it for one week before it was recalled for a problem with the rubber pads.  They were emitting a white chemical that was caustic and required washing your hands after holding he camera.  Canon recalled the camera and replaced the pads at no charge.  Unfortunatly, the repair took about two weeks with the shipment time, which was disappointing after enjoying the camera for the week I used it.  The camera is excellent, and the video mode is impressive, this is the best Rebel camera yet!  I upgraded from an XTi and this camera is about twice as nice, the processor is fast and the camera has more features than I will ever use.  Overall I have always loved Canon cameras, and this one is a real "keeper".

Reviews.Title: It's a great camera--except for one thing: WARNING
Reviews.Author: Joanna Daneman
Reviews.Content: The T4i is a great step up from the wildly popular T3i but there are some reasons NOT to buy it and either stick with the T3i or go to the T5i. Canon comes out with models rather frequently and it can be confusing to know which one to choose. This camera does a lot and is full of features, but there is a reason not to buy it and either stick with the T3i or go to a T5i.I'm coming right out and saying, I don't recommend the T4i. There are reports, confirmed by Canon that something in the rubberized plastic coating that covers the body gave some people a skin reaction. Apparently it is zinc. Do you have a metal allergy? A lot of people do. The grips got discolored in a short time and people reported getting an allergic reaction to the grips. I had to dig to find this, but it may be the reason the T5i, which has almost the same features, came out six months after the T4i. The T5i has a new coating that does not have this issue. There are a few improved features, but it's not a major change from the T4i. Rumor has it that the T4i will be discontinued due to the coating issue.The T4i has some better features over the T3iSilent autofocus during videoA stero micA TOUCHSCREEN (omg this is the best thing on a camera since autofocus)ISO goes up to 25,600, not 12,5009 cross type autofocus points instead of ONE center cross-typeNO DIFFERENCE: Low light peformance (noisy at low light)T4i vs new T5iThe new 18-55mm STM lens. The T5i is now sold with an 18-55 STM kit lens. This is a quieter lens, much better for video shooting and the 18-55mm size is a standard lens that is useful for on-the-go photography. If you don't use a long zoom lens, this lens is versatile. The upgrade to the "STM" version is really worth it.The T5i dial goes all the way around, you don't have to backtrack to go back to another settingCreative filters can be displayed as you take the photo (minor)HOW TO SAVE MONEY1. Buy the T3i on any good sale you see if none of the T4i or T5i improvements matter to you. This is one of those models that hits many sweet spots.2. Canon's site has refurbs at good prices from time to time at good prices (how I bought mine.) Some of the membership stores (the "C" store) have excellent deals on lens and body packages. I checked; it is true.I am happy with the T5i and SO HAPPY I did the research on the T4i to find out about the nickel-coating degradation issue because the price differential is NOT worth the trouble, and I ended up with a better model. I hope I helped you as well.Bottom line: if you tend to allergies, not recommended. If a discolored coating would annoy you, don't buy it. If neither of these issues matters to you and you find a great deal, it is a fine, fine camera.

Reviews.Title: Return for service..nearly right out of the box
Reviews.Author: Emilee
Reviews.Content: Used the T3i and was excited for this camera, the first few shots were great. Unfortunately not long after I purchased this (about 6 weeks)  it developed processing issues, it wont shoot video footage, and now it wont even process still pictures, due to some software or digital processing glitch. I have to send this camera back to Canon for warranty service, in the middle of the summer season. Hate to be disappointed after spending the better part of a thousand dollars on this kit.

Reviews.Title: LOVE IT!
Reviews.Author: Kevin Wagner
Reviews.Content: I really love this camera. The quality of photos and video are really amazing. Even in low light it's easy to get nice results if you have the correct settings. I mostly use manual mode for both photos and video. I hear people say you'll outgrow the kit lens, but for now it's all I'm using. I've taken a lot of nice shots and filmed some nice video. Someday I might get a better lens, but for now this does the job and I think it does it well. And when you shoot in RAW format, it's easy to fix images that you would have considered ruined. While playing around on the first day, I accidently messed up a few photos. I was able to take them and make them into great pics using the raw editing tools. I was quite surprised to see the battery lasted over 3 days of heavy use. I shot at least 10 minutes of video and over 600 photos. I went out 3 days in a row about 3-6 hours each day and hardly turned the camera off. The LCD screen does go off when it's against your chest (using the camera strap). There is also a power saving feature if you don't touch the camera in a while. I was considering the T3i but figured the 200 dollars would be worth it, even if it's just for the touch screen. I'm very happy with my decision.

Reviews.Title: Best DSLR Value, BUY IT!!
Reviews.Author: Jboogy Groove
Reviews.Content: Listen, there are a lot of great reviews going over various features, so I won't rehash those. I will simply say, I have a 60d, a 7d, and a T4i and the T4i wins hands down. The touch screen, articulating LCD, and the quality (continuous movie shooting) all make for the best camera you can get in this class. I looked at a ton of others. The Panasonic Lumix GH2 and 3 are great cameras, but I do not want to deal with the micro-thirds format and the picture quality in't great. The T5i is the same as the T4i, just a rebranding to get over the early models rubber grip issues and to progress the brand. The T4i is THE camera to get right now, I use it daily. Buy it, then buy a second one because at this price you can.

Reviews.Title: Great for beginners and Advanced users
Reviews.Author: J. Hall "Movieman"
Reviews.Content: I'm not gonna going over all the specs, there is pages and pages of that. What I will tell you is this is an amazing camera. I bought this camera for my wife as she was starting a photography business and needed something a little more high end without breaking the bank. After a lot of research we narrowed our search down and eventually settled on this carmera the T4i. Now since we have little to no experience with DSLR cameras our main reasons for purchasing the T4i are as follows...Easy to set up for a beginnerAuto mode is very user friendlyHas all the extended advanced options you could ever need (when you get to the point you're ready for them)Easy to navigate touchscreenLight and portableGreat color reproductionA huge user community to help with questionsAs we became more and more acquainted with DSLR cameras and features, we were happy to find that the T4i was still meeting all our needs, even the advanced ones. This is a great entry level camera with all the advanced features as well. We have been very happy with this choice and are sure you will be as well!

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera for HD video.
Reviews.Author: Adam G. Bender "adam b"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to use for HD video and I love it.  Before I purchased it, I thought the touch screen was just a fun, pointless feature.  It's actually been very useful.  When I'm capturing more documentary style videos, it's great to be able to change the exposure and other features on the fly.  All around this camera has great features for video, but I can't vouch for the photo side.

Reviews.Title: Another in a Long Line of Sucesses
Reviews.Author: Richard Hohn "Rixtar"
Reviews.Content: I bought the very first Digital Rebel (300D) and loved it.  I bought the Rebel T1i and the T2i and loved them both.  I buy a new DSLR every two years whether I need it or not.  The Canon T4i is yet another great moderately priced camera that offers some performance features you would expect to find on cameras costing hundreds of dollars more.  The picture quality is among the best so far as I can tell and the new touch screen makes using the camera easier than ever.  If someone wanted to buy their first DSLR camera I would recommend this camera without hesitation or reservation.  The layout of the buttons is more intuitive that some of the other brands I have seen and the included software adds value that any user will appreciate. The new focus system on this camera is great for video.  I have shot some video using my EFS 15-85 Canon Zoom Lens and found the results as good I could have hoped to achieve.  If this is your first DSLR, I recommend buying it with the 18-135 STM lens as the versatility is unmatched for both still and video photography.Update 5/1/2013 I have been using this camera daily and it continues to amaze.  I just purchased the 18-55 IS STM lens and it works very well. It is much better than the standard kit lens.  This is the best combination for video as with the lens attached the total weight is below the 2 pound limit for most economical video stabilizers.  I also started using the in camera Handheld night scenes this will make very easy to capture holiday lighting this coming December.

Reviews.Title: I upgraded from a T3i.. I just got it and i'm already impressed
Reviews.Author: Mark Lewis
Reviews.Content: So far it has worked well.... the new auto focus (versus the previous generations) is interesting and has worked well for the brief time i've used it so far.It has better light/low light sensitivity. Better video and the controls are improved so you can start-stop video recording independently. This is great for me as I intend to use the camera for both photos and video. This is an improvement over the previous generation and they have new lenses which take advantage of the auto focus for shooting video. Those supposedly have a quiet USM type motor which is silent.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Frank Furter "lawnboy4536"
Reviews.Content: BIG step up from xti, but uses the same lenses.  Picture quality is excellent.  Features easy to learn and use.The only thing keeping me from 5 stars is the way the built-in mic pics up camera noise, so bought an external mic for it.

Reviews.Title: Canon Rebel T4i
Reviews.Author: myReview
Reviews.Content: I had a Rebel XTi and this camera has many new features and it seems lighter as well.  I have enjoyed already the faster fps when trying to capture the kids and their sporting events both indoors and out.  I am currently using the XTi kit lens and 18-200 Telephoto lens so I con not comment on the newer lenses.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Wreckinball
Reviews.Content: After buying it I drove 7000 miles across the country and shot 2500 pictures and videos.  I have nothing to say but the camera was flawless.  I stepped up from a 2005 Canon Rebel DSLR.  The low light capabilities were fantastic while hiking around Carlsbad Caverns. I was able to get this with the 18-135 STM when it first came out (and it also is a non-recalled unit).

Reviews.Title: Best of the Rebel Series
Reviews.Author: Cesar Huitron
Reviews.Content: I have used Every Rebel made since Andre Agassi was doing commercials with them. I do 40% pictures and 60% video. The touch screen is more than a gimmick. It is surprisingly useful. The camera is light and sturdy. Will put through some trials this Spring when  photograph Supercells forming (I live in Tornado Alley) and filming American Bison in their annual rut while wearing a Ghillie suit. I've hated HDSLR's for video, but this one is probably the best one. Granted, it's a 1.6x sensor but I more than okay with that since most of my subjects are at a distance anyway and the cropping actually helps. The movable LCD flip screen makes video work a breeze. Can't do that on 5D Mk II, III or 7D. Loved that they finally figured out how to record continuously for up to 30 minutes, if you've used a 5D MkII or 7D, you know how frustrating itwas when your video clip stop recording after about 12 minutes. This was do to th FAT32 format which didn't allow the camera to record more than 4 GB at a time. It still IS that way, but now, a new clip forms seemlessly after 4GB are recorded. Couldn' do that with th 7D or 5DM2, it would stop completely and it would take like 3-5 seconds for you to start recording again. A major headache if you're videoing for a wedding or concert...

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera for serious amateurs.
Reviews.Author: G T Black
Reviews.Content: Summary: an excellent camera for serious amateurs, and would probably be a great second camera for pros.I have been an SLR photographer for over 40 years and a digital photographer for over 10, but this is my first foray into DSLRs.  After looking to see what the pros were using at airshows and the quality of photographs posted online I knew I wanted a Canon DSLR.  I first saw the T4i just after its introduction, and was able to directly compare it to the midrange (and more expensive) Canon EOS 60D.  I was sold on the smaller size and lighter weight of the T4i - a big plus for carrying it around airshows all day - without sacrifice in features and quality.  So far in the shooting tests I have performed with the camera it has met or exceeded my expectations, and I am starting to explore "second-level" menus.  The big surprise is how much I like using the touch screen controls.  Having never had them before I was skeptical, but have found them to be very fast and surprisingly intuitive.  I'll give the camera and lens a good workout when airshow season starts, but so far I am delighted.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS Rebel T4i
Reviews.Author: Yvonne Butler
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera primarily for the auto focus video and was disappointed in the performance. I read many other reviews but thought I would give the auto focus a chance.  It is slow to auto focus even with the 18-135 mm STM lens although there is a definite improvement over the 50 mm lens. Its auto focus is ok when there is left to right movement but it is slow to auto focus when something is coming towards the camera. I tested it informally against my iPhone and the iPhone performance was quicker. The camera is great for stills and some video situations. Love the touch screen! Almost worth keeping just for that!  The 18-135 mm lens is very sharp with excellent color and contrast after a little tweaking. Unfortunately I am very heavily invested in Canon SLR equipment so not anxious to change to another maker. I sent the camera back holding out for the Canon M which is still not available. From pre production reviews not so sure that it will do any better. So if auto focus video is your focus then think twice before purchasing. Otherwise go for it!

Reviews.Title: Flip screen back discoloring issue bothers me
Reviews.Author: H. Jiang
Reviews.Content: I purchased T4i with 18-135 STM. I took it to my vacation and shot a couple of hundred shots. I am very happy with it until I noticed that the back of the flip screen started to have a bright dark color patch and it is increasing in size. It seems that the top layer of the cover (paint?) begin to chip away after just 1 month use. It is obviously a quality control issue, but Amazon will not exchange it since it is out of 30 day window for 2 weeks. It maybe just cosmetic, but it really looks bad and my friend thought I bought a open boxed item. Really disappointed.UPDATE: I talked with Amazon, they agreed to replace my camera kit and I got it yesterday. I examined it more carefully and it was in brand new condition. Amazon did this even when my item was purchased outside 30 day window. I was very impressed with such a great customer service experience and ordered more stuff from them.

Reviews.Title: A great pro-sumer DSLR
Reviews.Author: Tim
Reviews.Content: If you're not getting paid for your photos, this will be all the camera you'll ever need. You can attach any Canon lens made for DSLRs (or third-party lenses with Canon mounts). Add any accessories you need. The battery grip is great for extended shooting. Add an LED video light or a flash, etc. Video mode on this camera is excellent, and if you use one of the new USM lenses for quiet focusing, you'll be set. There's very little you can't do with this camera that the bigger-brother "D" models can do.

Reviews.Title: Excellent bang for buck and great starter camera, but its worth spending more for the 70D if you are a photo enthusiast
Reviews.Author: Ruined
Reviews.Content: This camera is excellent much like Canon's other Rebel cameras, but it offers a few very useful upgrades over the T3i.First, it has a touchscreen - while some at first debated the usefulness of this, it is evident that the touchscreen is extremely helpful in determining if you got focus.  Instead of having to use a loupe, play with the arrows, or pray that you got everything in focus, now you can simply pinch to zoom exactly where you want to see if focus was locked.  Browsing photos is also more natural with the touchscreen, and you can touch to focus using the camera's liveview.Second, it supports video autofocus with especially good performance on the screw-type STM lenses such as the EF-S 18-135mm.  This type of lens is relatively quick in keeping focus unlike the micro motor and micro USM motors, even performing better than Ring USM for video (although Ring USM outperforms Screw-type STM for photos).  Note that the 40mm pancake uses a motor-based STM which is not as zippy as the screw-type STM in the 18-135mm.Third, it supports Chromatic Aberration correction in camera which is a bonus as it reduces post-processing time.Overall, this camera is a fantastic first camera.  However, if you are serious about getting in photography you might want to spend a little more and get the EOS 70D.  While the T4i is great, the sensor is not as good as the 70D and it is missing a lot of features compared to the 70D. Then again, it is going to cost you a decent amount more for the 70D so if your budget is straining with the T4i, don't hesitate in pulling the trigger as this camera is solid!  Note also that the t4i is very similar to the t5i.

Reviews.Title: If you get the T4i (or a T5i) - be sure get the STM lens(es)!
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey W.
Reviews.Content: Experience level:  I've been shooting since the early 1980s.  I've owned several 35mm cameras, other cameras, digitals, camcorders.  I've shot silly photos of family members, landscapes and buildings, and gorgeous sexy models.  I'm not a biased "cheerleader" for one brand:  I've owned Minolta, Pentax, Leica, and Canon.  I've shot about 7,000 photos with this particular camera so far.About this seller:  Awesome.  Fast.  Good price.  No BS'ing.  You click your mouse, and a few days later you get exactly what you wanted in the mail.Camera Pros:  This camera hits the "sweet spot" for features and price.  Silent lens (STM lens!) with stabilization and continuous focus make it a respectable dual purpose camera for video.  Zoom range is perfect for most applications, and I was able to buy a bargain adapter on Amazon to fit some of my very old manual-focus (Pentax) lenses, too!Camera Cons:  Fantastic for photos, but like many SLRs, when it comes to video it is still not a 100% match for a dedicated camcorder.  Still it is pretty respectable for video.  Though improved, focus sometimes has a slight lag (a known issue with Canon's recent generations).=====BUYING WAS A NICE EXPERIENCE:Delivery was fast.  Item was precisely as I expected it to be.  I had previously tried a T4i body with another lens bundle from Costco (that bundle was not an STM lens).  The noise from that lens was clearly audible when shooting video.  I didn't plan on shooting a lot of vid, but still I am shooting *some* video.  The "chirpchirpchirp" drove me nuts.So, I went to Amazon, and bought from this seller, and now things are great!ABOUT THE LENS:Thanks to the STM lens bundled with this camera, the focusing is COMPLETELY silent!  (YAY!)  The reach of the lens is extremely versatile.  To clarify, this is an 18-135mm lens projecting your photos onto a APS-C sized camera sensor (which acts as the "film" in the camera body).  If you're not buying an STM lens for this, you are abandoning much of the video/movie capabilities.A note for old-timers, from back in the time of 35mm film cameras:Some cameras have a full frame sensor (about the size of a 35mm film frame)  This is one of many cameras using a compact sensor.This just means that the bundled 18-135mm lens "translates" to what we used to regard as about 28-200mm.  I hope I don't confuse a lot of people with that, but those old-timers like me (who remember back to the days of 35mm film) might want to know that in your head, you multiply the lens specs by about 1.6x on a digital camera with a sensor of this size.  This is true of all APS-C digitals.  Nothing to worry about.  Just a side effect of the varying sensor sizes that are available.  Here's some more technical stuff about that, if anyone is interested:  [...]ABOUT THE BODY:True, this camera's grip is a little bit smaller than some other manufacturers, but I have rather big hands and it doesn't really bother me at all.  Try handling one at a retailer, and you'll see it isn't a big deal.The body is solid and lightweight.  The swing-out LCD is magnificent, and allows you to hold the camera high above your head for parades, or odd-angle photos; and still see the screen.  Battery seems to last me for about 500-700 shots.  The battery isn't bulky and a second battery is available dirt cheap (I've seen an independent manufacturer's 2-pack for less than $20), so if you need more than 500shots/charge, just snatch up an extra battery or two.PRICE, DELIVERY, ETC:Price was great.  Delivery was fast.T5i is basically the same camera, so price them both but realize you'll see very few changes between the models (Don't let the "5" fool you:  If you see a better price on T4i, do not hesitate to buy it!  Just make sure you are getting one of the STM family of lenses in your bundle!)OVER ALL:I would buy this camera again.  I would buy this camera for a loved one who knows a little about photography or who is looking into "branching out" into an SLR.  Not a day goes by without shooting!  The lens bundled in this configuration allows for great flexibility.It has been very reliable:  In the 7,000 or so shots I've taken, the camera only had one minor malfunction (it "panicked" when I kind of hit a lot of buttons at once by accident, so I just waited a minute or so, pulled the battery, and re-started the camera - and everything was fine)

Reviews.Title: Excellent DSLR for the non-professional
Reviews.Author: bmcdanel
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent DSLR for the non-professional.  I do a variety of near and far shots mostly under bright light.  I started to get the newer T5i.  However, except for being slightly smaller and lighter, the features were identical to the T4i and did not justify the $300 difference in price.  There were only minor changes in the settings and controls from my trusty EOS Rebel XSi that I've used for several years, making for an easy transition.  The 18-135mm STM lens is a significant improvement over the standard 18-55mm lens and worth the extra cost. I like the snappy performance and wider range of focal lengths, which make composing my shots easier with this most frequently used lens. All my older EF lenses work seamlessly with the T4i.  Whether taking snapshots or doing serious work, this camera delivers the most bang for the buck that a photographer could hope for.

Reviews.Title: 18-135 STM - fastest ever
Reviews.Author: Mr. D
Reviews.Content: I have 50mm 1.4f USM, 40mm STM, and 18-135mm STM.40mm STM is a little slow and noisy (but very small), like and 50mm is also slow (but more boke and good in low-light).But, 18-135mm STM is awesome, is ABSOLUTELY SILENT and incredible FAST!Even uncomparable to other lens I use before and after, lightspeed fast focusing! (not any movement back and forth, back and forth, trying to get focus....with this lens - BOOM! and in half second or less focus done)And its not all, picture quality is perfect, sharp, this lens with image stabilisation, and very good zoom range, from landscape to portrait with nice boke.I love it, is the best lens for everyone.This lens is perfect choice, you not regret!I'm highly recommend this lens to all.

Reviews.Title: Major Upgrade with an one issue
Reviews.Author: Powell
Reviews.Content: Love the articulating touchscreen. Love the 5 FPS. Love the pictures! Love the Camera! Don' buy it for the movie funtion. Much improved, but still not great.

Reviews.Title: Always the bests
Reviews.Author: T Sandeep Raj
Reviews.Content: Am new to the SLR world so I have been researching about cameras for more than an year and am totally convinced that Canon EOS Rebel T4i is exactly what i want. I don't talk much about technical things as am still learning but, all i can say is this is one of the best things i have purchased in recent times.

Reviews.Title: I adore this camera
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Akes
Reviews.Content: I shopped around and researched DSLR cameras for about 6 months before making this purchase.  I weighed the pros and cons of each and finally made the decision to purchase this make and model and I do not regret one second of that purchase.  I have been told many of my photos are so realistic you could actually reach in and touch the subject matter.  I use it for doing animal portraits, landscape shots, close up flower and nature shots, as well as several moon shots. I am very impressed with the flexibility of this unit and all the incredible things it can do.  Was a little intimidating at first but didn't take me long after playing with it to figure out what all it was capable of. Have done fire writing shots with this camera (moving a light source and creating designs on a slow shutter speed), I have used this camera to literally stop the flow of water or create movement by adjusting the film speed.  I love the lens and camera combination. It was an excellent starting point for someone wanting to get their feet wet in DSLR photography and now I am hooked and searching for additional equipment and lenses to further my new passion thanks to my experiences with this camera and lens combination.  There are several great tutorials on youtube for things you can do with this camera as well as many website dedicated to advancing your skills with this particular model. I highly recommend it and would suggest it to a friend or family member who is looking to get into photography.  Money very well spent.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Mohamed Elshoky
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for an entry level camera to the DSLR world, well this is the one for you. After I started using this camera I can never go back to any point and shoot camera. I had it for a week now so I'm not still an expert but there are things you can easily notice once you start using it:1- shutter speed is amazing, the 5 frames per second captures great sequence of pictures2- The touch screen is an amazing feature if you love touch screens3- the 18-135 lens is a very good starting zoom lens that is recommended over the 18-55 lenses as it will spare you some time before wishing to have a new zoom lens4- The size of the camera is not annoying to carry it with you in all your tripsThat are plenty of detailed reviews for thid camera so I will not repeat them but my advice is if you are thinking of getting this camera then you are making a good choice.

Reviews.Title: Great Upgrade Over My Previous Camera
Reviews.Author: JoAnn V.
Reviews.Content: I'm not a digital camera expert so I won't even attempt to describe or rate specific features but I will say that the photos produced by this camera made my jaw drop when I saw the first ones. The clarity and resolution are nothing short of amazing. I'm using the dummy mode (auto) at first so I can imagine that as I become more familiar with the settings and how to use them, my satisfaction will increase dramatically. I also love the LCD screen and the fact that it can be swiveled. I bought this to replace my 11 year old Nikon Coolpix 4500 that I never was very happy with and I'm glad that I did.**** On an related but very troublesome side note, and since the "review the seller" and "Packaging" feedback options are conspicuously absent from only this transaction in my account, I should warn others about the appalling lack of any padding or any effort at all to protect this camera and the accessory lens that I purchased with it. Amazon's staff simply dropped almost $900.00 worth of fragile digital camera equipment into a box, taped it up and shipped it that way. The box arrived smashed in but the camera and lens seem to have survived. I ordered this as a gift and needless to say, I'm not too happy about this issue. I order here frequently and routinely receive non-fragile items like lawn mower belts, for instance, that have been padded with literally 9 feet of air bags, yet Amazon's staff handle and ship expensive digital cameras as though they are worthless to them and to their customer. Due to this, I will not be ordering any sort of high dollar, fragile items here in the future.

Reviews.Title: Excellent package...
Reviews.Author: Michael Lawler
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with my new camera and the lens that came with it I'd recommend this package to anyone who needs a high quality camera.

Reviews.Title: Meets my expectations 100%
Reviews.Author: Art
Reviews.Content: The camera is just great. It does everything as expected. The 18-135mm Lens is also very good. One of course does see that it is not the most expensive lens, but the generated pictures are just great. And by the way, much better then the standard 18-55mm lens.One thing what I don't like about this camera is, that the Canon firmware isn't really useful besides standard photo-shootings. I would love for example change the burst rate, i.e. shoot in burst mode but with longer period. Or for example why not offer a feature of multiple-exposures, where I can expose the same picture several times. There are tons of possibilities I could imagine one could use the camera for, but it seems in this case, I would need to program it myself through an API offered by Canon SDK or just install 3rd party firmware on the camera :)But by the end of the day, the camera would not make you a good photographer it is just a better tool.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Upgrade!
Reviews.Author: Sarge
Reviews.Content: Upgraded from the first Rebel to this one and as expected, a dramatic difference, especially with the STM lens that came with it.  In the two month period I have owned this camera, I've shot everything from landscapes, sports, portraits, closeups and movies.  The images and colors are just fantastic to this untrained photographer's eyes.  Where before I just dabbled in taking stills and some family photos, I am having a lot of fun now.  The auto mode overcomes my laziness to make manual adjustments, especially when changing lenses trying to capture live action events.  The video mode is a new feature to me as I usually use a video camera for live shots.  It is actually becoming more useful and fun as I get more experienced on how and when to use it, especially with STM/USM lenses in manual mode.  Unfortunately for me, this camera pretty much rendered my older zoom lenses and filters useless and that's where my costs for owning this camera have skyrocketed.  The USM zoom lenses with stabilization mode, while not quite L quality, are not cheap so in retrospect I may have gone with the T3i, which has most of the same features and quality of this camera, to offset the cost of replacing my older 75-300 lens/filter (I replaced it with the USM 70-300/filter/hood).  Still, I made my decision and am very happy with what's in my bag.  I am heading to Alaska in July and can't wait to use this camera there, perhaps I'll do a review update then.  An important clarification on my older lenses.  They still fit however, from a functional standpoint (stabilization and USM), I needed better zoom lenses to compliment this camera's capabilities.

Reviews.Title: Great Sports Shots
Reviews.Author: carstok
Reviews.Content: I just upgraded from a Canon I had for about 4 years.  So far I have taken basketball photos of my kids teams.  Never had a good shot in that horrible gym lighting.  So excited about the camera so far, but have not used a lot yet to use all the features.One of the best decisions was to choose the one with the 18-135 lens.  I was so tired of switching my lens so often.After the games I would forget to change my lens and had to stand half way down the court to get a team photo.

Reviews.Title: Great Entry Level DSLR Kit.
Reviews.Author: KW58
Reviews.Content: Up front:  Initial rating, will update after some use.Did a lot of research online and in person before deciding between this and the 60d.  Initially chose Canon because of the ergonomics and better video quality despite having a couple Nikon fans in the family. So far, so good.  We have used 90% auto mode, and tried to branch out and learn the other modes as we can.  For a beginner to DSLR, I think a usable Auto mode is an important feature, and this one has been great so far.  The other features do what they're described to do, we just need to get smarter on advanced photography to make an accurate judge of them.As previous reviewers have said, the autofocus tends to "hunt" in video mode if shooting moving objects, but it's tolerable, and we don't intend to use this as a camcorder, so much as take a few short clips when we're out shooting pictures.  Doesn't seem like you can find any DSLR that does video on par with a digital camcorder.As far as burst speed in still mode, two observations:1)  Get a high-speed memory card (this is true of all DSLRs with the burst feature, and Amazon has the pretty cheap)2)  The image buffer isn't as big as on say the 60d.  The end result is that for the first second or two, you can maintain the advertised 5+ FPS, but once that buffer fills up (length of time depends on shooting mode), the burst speed will slow down significantly.  I knew this before I bought, and I'm not a sports photographer, so it's not a game changer for me.  Just be aware if a continuous burst rate is important to you.

Reviews.Title: Very happy with our purchase
Reviews.Author: Patrick S.
Reviews.Content: I read a lot about cameras online before purchasing this our first DSLR camera spurred on by the coming birth of our first child. I wasn't sure if I should spend more to get a low end 'semiprofessional' camera or whether this camera would satisfy my needs if I later got really in to photography. I can now say that this camera has plenty of features and complexity to keep me happy and I am glad at this point that I didn't spend more to get a more high end camera.  For one it is not too big. My amateur photographer friend recommended this camera to me because she got a 'better', but larger and heavier camera that she sometimes just doesn't want to lug around on vacation. I didn't want the size of a camera to get in the way. Don't get me wrong, you'll need a case and you aren't going to slip this thing in your pocket anytime soon like a point and shoot, but I wouldn't want it any bigger or heavier.  From the first picture we took on Christmas day with me jumping into the air with my new bright orange soccer shoes on and the shutter speed set really fast to minimize blur we were blown away by the picture quality and sharpness. It was unlike any picture we had ever taken before with a point and shoot. If you are new to photography you will have plenty to learn about and experiment with by adjusting shutter speed, aperture size, and ISO if you like this sort of thing to keep you occupied for a long time.  I found the site kenrockwell.com to be well done and very helpful when picking a camera. It was on his recommendation that I opted to go for the 18-135mm lens and I am so glad I did. If you think about it buying a second extra lens means a large extra expense, carrying two lenses with you if you are out, and potentially having to change the lens outside under less than ideal conditions. With this one lens we can take a wide range of photos without ever having to change. Its awesome and dead quiet. I don't know enough to tell you what you might sacrifice with this one size fits all lens, but for me its a perfect fit.  The touch screen is a nice feature too which allows you to change settings quickly and works well.

Reviews.Title: Great. Get the better lens kit.
Reviews.Author: Mary
Reviews.Content: I am an amateur photographer. I just started a photography class and this camera is the one for me. I briefly considered the T3i which is very similar but in the end decided to go with the newer model. Technology depreciates and becomes obsolete so fast that if you don't get the newest model of something, you fall behind. At least that is my opinion.I recommend this version of the t4i that comes with the better lens. The lens is a $450 lens where as the lower model lens kit comes with the $90 lens. You only pay $200 more for the better lens. In my eyes it is the obvious choice. The lens is fantastic. It covers a large range (for a beginner) and photographs fantastic pictures. Camera bodies will be replaced over years if you stay in photography, but lenses can be kept. Thats why I chose to INVEST in the better lens.The whole package is a fantastic purchase.

Reviews.Title: the great wait
Reviews.Author: greg
Reviews.Content: long time fan of Canon productshave had slr's and flashes and lensto getting this was a big trip for mei got it just under a monthand i am still on cloud ninei have taken shoots of about everythingso farfunny thing is when u were first on filmu have to wait for developingbut not with this the great wait is nowhow long till i am home to see all on the computer

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: April D. Kitchen
Reviews.Content: The touch screen is great and the AF works wonderfully.  This is more first camera on the expensive side, but I've always taken pictures, usually using my $100 Canon Cameras.  I would definitely recommend this to any first time camera purchaser.  The touch screen is awesome and the camera itself is user friendly.

Reviews.Title: Very enjoyable to use
Reviews.Author: Liz "lizurd6"
Reviews.Content: I own a Canon 20D and was interested in the higher resolution of the newer cameras. But I dont have as much time these days so I also wanted something a little simpler, or with better automatic features. I took this camera out on a whale watching trip (picture zodiac type boat rocking, trying to get that photo in the instant the whale appears). This camera performed fabulously, and a few adjustments like bracketing and continuous shooting enabled me to get some "WOW" shots that were crisp and poster quality. I am totally excited about this camera. I could wish it to be smaller (I had tried the smaller G1X but the shutter speed of that is way slower than this one.), but looking at the results, I will suck that up. I am excited about taking great photos again!

Reviews.Title: Couldn't Live Without It
Reviews.Author: Min
Reviews.Content: Anybody looking to get into photography and/or videography should look no further. This is a great camera for the price and is packed with features. If you're looking to use the video feature, the swivel screen is so handy. If you're super serious the stereo mic isn't too important, but it's easily one of the best mics on a DSLR. I've found that I don't use the touch screen that much, but it really does help when you need to switch some settings quickly. I've always told people if you're just getting into photography, don't look to invest in the body too much, invest in lenses. Save some money, get this body, and look up to pick up another lens.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: Bob Dean
Reviews.Content: I haven't had this camera very long but I can't stop taking pictures with it.  Granted I am an amateur who has been using my iPhone camera (which is very convenient and takes pretty amazing pictures for a phone), but this camera opens up all new doors. I took 70 inside pictures on Christmas Day and didn't have to use a flash in low light. The pictures give that warm and cozy feeling that I couldn't get with cheaper cameras.  It will take me a while to learn all the things this camera can do but I was able to start using it almost right out of the box. If you have stopped taking lots of pictures because of the limitations of using cheap cameras, this camera will inspire you to reach a whole new level.

Reviews.Title: Amazing stills, amazing video
Reviews.Author: Jason
Reviews.Content: This replaced my beloved EOS Rebel XSi which snapped 50,000 pictures in the years I owned it.  So the T4i had a lot to live up to and it does it without any trouble at all.  It's faster, clearer, easier to use, has more features and shoots incredible video.  Once you have a video camera with replaceable lenses you'll never go back.My only gripe is the autofocus motor noise when recording video.  The mic sits right on top of the camera and if you don't have a STM lens you'll hear the autofocus motor.  I just ordered an external mic so that should solve the problem.Other than that Canon hit a home run with this one.

Reviews.Title: Best Rebel I Ever Had
Reviews.Author: Mister Fenster
Reviews.Content: There are dozens of reviews on the Web for this camera and I'm not going there. This one is way better than my 3 year old Rebel. Auto focus is very good on this camera. It will just about focus in the dark. It has a sensor on the back that turns off the display when you go to look through the viewfinder. My Metz flash that I already had works fine with this camera and so does my Tamron 10-24 lens.I have no post-purchase regrets.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Cheryl Lowery
Reviews.Content: I really hesitated on upgrading from the Canon Xsi to the T4i but am so glad I did.  The Xsi took great pics but the T4i takes awesome pictures.  Photography is a hobby and my three grandchildren are my favorite subjects.  Although the kids are always on the move, I have captured some really great pics.  For example, the pic was amazing of my grandson riding his Razor electric scooter at full speed.  Very impressed with this camera and it will be a long time before I upgrade.  I have never been into video and I didn't buy it for that purpose so I won't comment on that aspect.  My favorite feature is the responsive touch screen, which makes changing functions so quick and easy.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera for the price!
Reviews.Author: LindsayW
Reviews.Content: I have been so happy with this camera. The new scene-intelligent auto setting is fantastic! I actually bought this camera to replace our really old Nikon at work and mainly use it to capture photos of company events -- which means I don't have a lot of time to mess with aperture, ISO and shutter speed. So I love how crisp and perfect my photos look even in auto mode.Canon has also made this camera quieter. Gone is the familiar loud click when you snap a photo -- here to stay is a quieter snap sound that's not as distracting (and would probably be good when you're shooting wildlife).Finally, the video from this camera is amazing. I have only shot one short video so far, but the camera was easy to use and delivered flawless HD video.Bottom line: Buy this camera. You won't be disappointed. I want one of my own now to replace my T2i.

Reviews.Title: what an excellent camera for video too
Reviews.Author: Grant Johnson
Reviews.Content: This camera takes great pictures, tons of detail, and the video feature is the main reason I got it. What huge wonderful HD flowing pictures it takes, beautiful, and all at true HD resolution, not that HDV stuff on most video camcorders...  this is the real deal. Great colors. Hardly any grain.  Even lower light situations have low grain.  I am very impressed. The card loads right into a computer for ingesting into FCPX, etc.  SO easy.

Reviews.Title: Nice upgrade from the T3i
Reviews.Author: Comdet
Reviews.Content: I had been borrowing a T3i for the times when I wanted something more lightweight and portable than my 5D Mark II. Given all the time I was spending with the T3i, I thought it was time to get my own.I was torn between the T3i and the T4i but Amazon made it easy since they were both priced the same before Christmas. So, I went for the T4i, and am very glad I did. It's a nice improvement over the T3i.The most telling upgrade has been the touch screen. I admit I was a bit wary of this since I'm comfortable with the traditional buttons, menus and rocker switches. After using it for a few days I very much miss having it on my other Canons. Very responsive, allows me to jump to a setting more quickly, and just plain easy and fun to use!I do have to admit that Canon's claim that this is a "smudge resistant" screen is only partially true. It sort of, kind of resists smudges, but I usually end up cleaning the screen a few times during use.The other novel feature of the T4i is the ability to have continuous autofocus in movie mode. I'm more of a still photographer than a videographer, so that's does not make a huge impact for me. However, I have used it and it does work very well - I may start shooting more video now, and am considering getting the 40mm STM lens (although the continual autofocus works with any lens, it's best suited with an STM lens).Most of the specs of the T4i are identical to the T3i; a few have been tweaked, such as a higher frame rate, higher ISO and faster processor.I was a no-brainer for me to get the T4i when it was priced the same as the T3i. But now that I've had it for a while, I certainly think the added features make it a worthwhile choice over the T3i even at a higher price. It you purchased a T3i recently, it's probably best to wait for the inevitable T5i whenever it comes out rather than upgrade now. But, if you're debating between the T3i and the T4i, go for the 4, if only for the touchscreen.

Reviews.Title: Defective Item
Reviews.Author: Sudarshan Seshadri
Reviews.Content: I ordered the T4i with STM lens. Really happy with the lens,but camera had a couple of problems1. Freezing - froze half a dozen times in just one week of low usage (~50 shots a day). Only way to fix this is remove battery2. Optical Viewfinder - For some strange reason the viewfinder was just not clear. I had to rely on AF rather than actually seeing the subject clearly. Also, the setting snapshot that we see below the subject in the viewfinder was just not clear.Compared it with another t4i which had no such issues over the last few months. So forced to return it to Amazon. Really disappointed with the lack of quality from Canon.That said, image quality is really great. I have written a separate review on the STM lens.I am sure many have said this, but i would like to repeat  - Buy this with STM lens ONLY. Both STMs out there are really worth it and I have seen little/no difference in image quality when compared to some of the L series.Video mode has been mentioned by reviewers as a good try but not there yet - i've found the AF coupled with half press (in effect manual focus) for fast moving subjects does the job decently.I am waiting for Amazon to send me new one and hoping it to be defect free. Will update my rating post receiving it, but till then i would be cautiously optimistic in saying without the mentioned defects (1 in 10 pieces would be like this), this camera is a really good buy, esp now that the prices have dropped.Buy the 40mm STM pancake along with the camera. You might prefer zoom lens to prime, but this is so small and sharp you will not leave it anywhere. IMO the two STM lenses make the T4i arguably the best choice for <$1000 DLSR.

Reviews.Title: Step above entry level
Reviews.Author: Charlie
Reviews.Content: This is truly an amazing camera with a "must have" lens. This camera is the best in it's class, leaving the Nikon d3200 and the D5100 in the dust. It's amazing picture quality, in camera HDR, articulating screen (touch screen), support of the new silent STM lenses, continuous AF while recording video, and many other features make this camera a winner. If you plan on shooting video, make sure you buy this package with the STM lens, otherwise you'll hear your other lenses focusing during playback. I got this on promotion with a second lens (55-200mm) for $150 and a free bag/memory card. You won't regret this purchase. This is a Nikon eater!

Reviews.Title: Top quality consumer grade DSLR
Reviews.Author: A. Williams
Reviews.Content: I upgraded from the t1i (500D) to this t4i (650D) and am very glad I did. Compared to the older body, this has a better screen (movable, and touch-sensitive), a better focusing system, and much better low-light performance. There are many other improvements, but these are what matter most to me. The t4i is a couple of ounces heavier than the t1i, but the improvements justify this for me. Highly recommended! Since the question is sometimes asked, let me note that my t4i was Made in Japan.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Ryan978
Reviews.Content: I upgraded from the Canon T2i to the T4i, the swivel and touch screen is really well thought out and the touch screen is extremely responsive. The screen has a really wide viewing angle which is really nice. The new Digic 5 processor is fantastic as well.

Reviews.Title: Best Learning Camera for beginner, better than T3i brother due to Touch Screen & HDR, Hand Held night mode
Reviews.Author: Anurag
Reviews.Content: Yes i mean it when i say fastest camera to use all of its features, basically the touch screen feature on this camera make it possible to quickly change the settings and get familiar with the settings which any entry to medio-cor camera user will not able to find using the manual control buttons. I know touch is not necessary feature in DSLR but say it after using the camera for at least one day during the night time photography when you have to quickly change the aperture and shutter settings. It gives the fastest possible way to without letting your subject wait to long while you are hunting for the exact setting trying to adjust via control buttons (infact you would have already taken 3 shots in the same time with added touch feature). Another nice feature i found in it was hand held night photography mode which allows you to automatically take 4 shots together and then merge them to provide you the picture without blurring anything. this is very useful feature when you are taking pictures without the hazzle of carrying tripod with you. i also observed that this mode is better that auto mode in terms of picture quality/sharpness and contrast for night photography although you have to wait 3 to 5 seconds to let your camera merge all 4 shots to generate single picture with wow effect. Love it more than my earlier purchase of t3i which ended up in returning the product as t4i is better choice for the extra money i spent. i also felt that focusing system is little faster with any lens you use due to cross point 9 focus system, more telescopic lens you use, more you will feel that its faster than t3i model. decision maker point for me was its touch screen and autofocus system which made me fan of it as it was my first DSLR camera after using high zoom point & shoot camera. i know within one year i would be done by it as i already learned lot of things using it and feeling to get one more step ahead with higher end camera and thanks to touch screen which helped me a lot in my learning curve otherwise this learning path could be more longer for me. So if you are new in this field and want to learn first before investing huge amount of money in camera and lenses, please go ahead and buy it...I am sure that you won't be regretted. I have gone through all of the reviews and comparisons of different canon eos rebel models & 60D its most close competitor but after using t4i for 3 days i found that all thos low findings or drawbacks or cons were rarely noticeable until you stand with professional who can bring the difference to your notice by pointing the finger at the picture in 200% zoom ratio. I have Canon t4i + 18-55 mm kit lens + 50-250mm IS II zoom lens and 50mm 1.8 II lens in my bundle and i am satisfied as of now. I think i will jump on to more costly lens only when my learning curve with t4i is done and will upgrade to next level of camera. till then all the best to all enthusiast buyers of this product. you don't need second thought if this is your first DSLR camera.
