Reviews.Title: Mixed report on Canon T4i
Reviews.Author: Photocat
Reviews.Content: I just received the Canon T4i and 18-135 lens through Amazon a couple of days ago and have shot approximately 1,500 shots since then.First the good:I have been comparing the AF focusing system with that of my T3i using a 50mm f/1.4 Canon lens in fairly dark conditions.In the non-live view mode, the 9 AF points in the T4i are all cross-type while only the center AF point in the T3i is a cross-type.In non-live view, the non-center AF points in the T4i focus better than the center AF point in the T3i even though both the T4i and T3i are supposed to have the same high-precision cross-type center AF point.In live view, the T4i also appears to be focusing much better than the T3i. Surprisingly, in the quick mode AF method, the live view in the T4i allows the transfer of the actual AF points not just a general moveable area that is available with the T3i in the live view AF mode quick mode.The Bad:I thought I had received an exceptionally good copy of the T4i until it began to intermittently freeze up such that I have to shut it off, take out the battery and restart. I am using a fast 32GB memory card and was not shooting in burst mode when it froze up. I was shooting single shot and not quickly. I aleady sold the kit lens that comes with it so asked Amazon to replace the body only. They cannot replace the body without the lens and told me to contact Canon for repairs.Also, please note that I did not anticipate that Adobe Camera Raw of CS5 would not work with the T4i even with using the plugin and updates. While this is not Canon's fault, you have to update to CS6 to process raw photos taken with the T4i. Since I always shoot in raw, this is a major problem for me. So now I have to come up with hundreds of dollars to buy CS6 or use Canon's Digital Photo Professional DPP) to process my raw photos. DPP is not as user friendly nor as effective as Adobe Camera Raw in my opinion.In summary, I was very happy with the new focusing system of the T4i but am not happy that I have to send it in for freezing up repairs already.1-22-12 UpdateI just received the T4i repaired back from Canon two days ago. It was found that the circuit board caused the camera to freeze from time to time. The circuit board was replaced. It now functions well. The improvement in low light focus over my T3i (that I kept as a back-up) is drammatic. The colors, clarity, and crispness of the shots are significantly improved as well. I practiced using my T4i with my two 600EX-RT Speedlites using radio transmision and the combination are exceptional. Rather than using a OCF E-TTL Cord (which I have) to get the master off camera, I experimented bouncing the on-camera flash into a reflector on a stand and it gave a soft, beautiful key light. I used the off-camera 600EX-RT as a hair light at 1:8 power in E-TTL and it worked great. I am changing my review to five stars after the repair from Canon.

Reviews.Title: The perfect camera for someone who wants to explore making a transition into pro level photography and filmmaking.
Reviews.Author: John P. Thiel "John P. Thiel"
Reviews.Content: Adding to my earlier review, I wrote the following to answer a question about shooting video on the T4i:Allow me to gush.  It's freakin' gorgeous!  You can get that true movie look with the T4i and unlike other DSLRs, the STM lenses made for this camera are virtually silent.  There are all sorts of videos on YouTube telling you otherwise, but they must have been using another non-STM (STep Motor) lens.I've spoken to professional filmmakers who raved about the T3i--now a dinosaur by comparison--saying they shoot entire feature films on them.Anyway, you can definitely take pro level video with this camera using the STM lenses.So why does anyone use a movie camera anymore?  There are all sorts of reasons including the fact that the pros don't use autofocus and therefore don't need a virtually silent autofocus motor, but if you want real movie making bang for your buck that an amateur with little to no training can use, this is it.One other recommendation: Get some kind of video editing software.  There are a lot of great, cheap programs out there.  On my iPad I first used iMovie and now I'm learning how to use Pinnacle Studio because it's a lot more capable.  Either one only costs about $25.LONG, UNEDITED SHOTS: If you're looking to shoot an entire school play or sightseeing trip from start to finish, non-stop, and have no desire to improve your video shooting skills, then consider this: People who do real movie making take very short shots, ten to thirty seconds max, and then put them together in editing.  I forget exactly, but I think the T4i will stop recording video automatically at ten or fifteen minutes to prevent overheating.So if you were looking to shoot an entire school play or wedding from start to finish, uninterrupted, you would be better off with a dedicated video camera.A better solution is to go ahead and buy this camera, and also buy a book called How to Shoot Video That Doesn't Suck: Advice to Make Any Amateur Look Like a Pro which is also sold here on Amazon.  Then not only will you shoot better video with your T4i, but people will actually want to watch it.  After reading that book, I took a video of my wife getting a haircut, set it to music, and it's actually part of my portfolio now--a less than two minute video of a haircut!WEIGHT:  Another issue is weight.  A DSLR doesn't seem heavy until you've had to hold it up for more than a minute.  You could use a monopod, but if you want to go handheld for those long shots of the ballet recital, then a smaller, lighter video camera is the way to go.  Professionals shooting video handheld will typically have the camera resting on their shoulder both for stability and just plain endurance.  Amateurs will use super light cameras so they don't get tired holding them.----------------------------------------------It's referred to as an entry-level DSLR but that's only in comparison to cameras that have capabilities you would likely never, ever use.  Look at that shutter speed, the ISO range, then ask yourself what extreme conditions would require a 'better' camera.  In fact I showed it to a professional photographer friend of mine and said, "You must have really super cameras way better than this," and he replied, "No.  This is as good as any of my cameras for nearly all shots."  And he liked the touch screen.If this is your first fully manual camera and you're feeling a bit intimidated by the learning curve, don't worry because it has plenty of automatic functions to make you look like you know what you're doing even if you never quite get the hang of all the settings.  Even if you used it purely on automatic, the capability of this camera versus a point and shoot is going to translate into better pictures.If nothing else, you can try a few shots in fully automatic, and then try shooting manual with similar settings just to see what happens.  It's digital, so free shots, and no regrets.As the Natasha Bedingfield song says, "Release your inhibitions."Those of you who finally made the switch from 35mm film SLR cameras are not going to miss choosing the right film with the right ISO for whatever you plan to shoot because you can change this shot by shot in this camera, but you will miss the fact that shutter speed and aperture (f-stop) can only be set via the display screen.  These settings don't appear on the dial or the lens body.Still, just like you became accustomed to 'auto advance' versus flipping a lever to get to the next film frame, you will make the adjustment.  Especially if you have trouble seeing tiny numbers you will likely appreciate the display more and more.Also, the display tells you basically what making a change one way or the other will mean, such as lighter or darker, slow or fast.  It's not so much treating you like an idiot as making it idiot proof.If only they had taken the additional bold step of renaming things like Tv mode (Time Value) appropriately "Shutter Priority" and so forth, that would have been nice for both the veterans and newcomers alike, but I suppose some things never change.And lastly, I've read and seen reviews on YouTube which discussed that the lens motor does make some noise and that it doesn't focus as quickly as they wish it did.  While that may be true of the smaller 18 to 55mm kit lens it's not true of the 18 to 135mm STM lens.  It's completely silent.  I don't even here it on video playback.  And I was a musician, so I would notice.  And no problems with continuous focus as long as you have chosen the correct auto focus setting for your shot--there are three of these by the way.Bottom Line:  I love it.  This is a wonderful camera.

Reviews.Author: J. Fulton
Reviews.Content: My primary reason for upgrading to this camera was my hope that the video autofocus system would be good enough to allow me to stop carrying both a camera and a camcorder. If you are looking at this camera for that reason then do NOT buy it.The autofocus system for video is horrible, absolutely awful. I have the 40mm STM lens, which is supposed to increase speed and reduce the background noise. It is much quieter but as far as I can tell, it hunts for correct focus just as often and takes just as long as any of my other lenses.If you want video at a fixed distance where you set the shot up in advance and both the camera and subject are still, then the video quality is excellent. Though I can't recommend strong enough that you disable autofocus after you set up the shot. I have had countless instances in which after some period of time taking a video shot at a FIXED distance, the camera suddenly goes out of focus and then works its way back into focus. Ridiculous! So let the autofocus find the correct initial focus in normal photo mode, then disable the autofocus on the lens and switch to video.As far as video of a moving target, don't waste your time or endure the frustrations of trying to get the canon to maintain or find focus on a moving target. Its ridiculous. It hunts continuously, rechecks itself by going out of focus then trying to get back in, often failing to find focus for 5-10 seconds. There are many videos out there on the internet reviewing the autofocus of this camera and it is universally blasted for any moving subject.I have had far better success at using the manual focus to track a moving target than I have turning the function over to the camera.In all other respects the image quality is very nice and like previous rebels it includes a nice mix of features but if you came to this camera (or any successive camera using this autofocus design) in the hopes of getting a robust autofocus system for video do not buy it.

Reviews.Title: Better focus than my T1i
Reviews.Author: TGP
Reviews.Content: I purchased this a gift for my son. While comparing my T1i rebel to the new T4i I found that the focus on the new T4i is much better than on my T1i. I fly radio controlled airplanes and frequently take pictures at flying events. The new T4i seems to be able to focus better on moving objects while in full auto mode. My old T1i has to be set in program mode and spot metering and center point focus to get a good picture. When comparing the new and the old rebels it is obvious that he will be able to take more pictures in full auto and not have to manually adjust the camera himself. Since this is his first DSLR camera it should be an easier adjustment since he has only owned point and shoot cameras in the past. I'm sure he will start to investigate the other feature eventually but will have good pictures right away because of the difference in the focus.I was originally only looking at camera bodies expecting to have to buy a lens and I was glad to see for a $1 you could add the 18-55 mm lens in this combo.

Reviews.Title: Excellent photos, camera needs improvement
Reviews.Author: Legal Eagle
Reviews.Content: I have been an amateur photographer for 60 years.  My first camera was a Kodak Brownie Hawkeye.  I learned photography with a 35mm camera with a separate, hand-held light meter, and a depth of field chart.  I had to manually set the distance, F number, shutter speed and film speed.  Now, we have DSLR cameras that automate many to all of these functions.  My newest camera is the Canon Rebel T4i with 18 to 135mm kit lens.  At the present time, I also own the Canon Powershot G15 and the SX40.The bottom line is that the T4i takes excellent photos.  This morning I took 446 photos of the Laguna Niguel (CA) Christmas Parade, all on one battery charge.  (I used the viewfinder rather than the LCD screen.)  The battery was still working fine after the photo shoot.  Such a large number of photos is unbelievable.  Here are all the photos I took on my Facebook page:  [...] I posted every single photo.  I did not delete any.  You can view these photos to judge for yourself.  I recognize that a person can take terrible photos with any camera, no matter the quality or the price.Although I gave my rating 5 stars, I would have preferred 4.5 stars.  The camera should be improved.  The menu system is a mess.  The touch screen is screwed up.  I recognize that an entry level DSLR should be difficult to learn to justify the higher price!  The menu system on the G15 is much better.  Canon should test their cameras with select users for comments before they are released. The menu system should be completely intuitive, the T4i is not.  I am not saying that the menu system is real bad, but it can be and should be improved.  Canon can do better.  Tell me why the G15 has a better menu system than the T4i?  It doesn't make any sense.If you want an excellent DSLR that isn't overweight and takes really excellent photos, buy the T4i!  But only with the kit 18 to 135 zoom lens.  I could not have taken the photos I did today using two separate lens.  Life is too short to tolerate such nonsense.

Now that I have it I realize I don't really like the touch screen or the fold out screen that much, and it is a bit annoying if you want to do fairly straightforward photography with it. However, the pictures are clear and high quality. It shoots well in lower light than my old camera. The body feels strangely cheap and light, and I absolutely hate the way it works with autofocus (also hate the continuous servo option... one of the first things I had to do was figure out how to turn that off). In short, it does a lot that I don't really need and feels like it is more marketed to gear heads who want a swiss army knife, when really I like a shooting experience that isn't too far from shooting with film.On the up side it works with all of my existing glass. I'm not sorry I bought it, because my old camera was desperately behind in picture quality, but am pretty sure there are a lot of features here that I am just not really going to use. The price is good though, so I can't complain about that.

Reviews.Title: Great step up from P&S;
Reviews.Author: ck
Reviews.Content: Great all around. Buy if you know what an SLR is and you want to make the leap out of P&S.; This camera would serve well as a P&S; (probably 80% of my pics), but that will only scratch the surface.Cons:Big & bulky (as are all SLRs) - my wife is not likely to tote this around to various events to take pics of the kidsHigher cost = nervous wife who may feel like she has to treat it like a delicate flower (she'll get over it)Shots with flash - thus far I am not impressed and somewhat disappointed with flash photography for every day events (using pop up flash). Some of this may be getting used to a longer lens (flash either won't reach when zoomed in or long lens casts a shadow when shooting close up); I am surprised to find that pics with flash are coming out slightly blurry (which is counter-intuitive). -- This is the reason for 4 stars (not 5)Pros:Great glass - pics are much improved over P&S; (I have used mostly Canon P&S;).Manual control - though most users will probably not botherHand-held Night Scene Mode: Outstanding! Takes 4 quick shots and combines them for proper exposure. In many situations, I prefer this to using flash (though will not always work). Great for indoor portraits / group shots.NEED TO KNOW:Flash card: you WILL NEED to buy a high speed SD card if you plan to take videos. Don't bother with the intermediates - go straight to the highest speed (currently Class 10 - US-1?). Not cheap - a decent size card will cost as much as $90-100 but you can shop sales (I found a 16mb for $40 on sale).Best investment for this camera will be a $20 UV lens filter - primary purpose is to protect your expensive new glass; buy this immediately and put it on the lens before you get too far down the road.

Reviews.Title: 4 Stars Camera, 1 Star amazon.com treatment of customers
Reviews.Author: JCF
Reviews.Content: No complaints about the camera... so far I'm enjoying it. However, there was an offer on amazon.com for a lens with $100 off. Yes, it was my fault... I was in a hurry because I was leaving for the airport and yes, I've learned I should not purchase items from amazon.com when I'm in a hurry. I'm a long-time amazon.com customer both professionally and personally. I was probably one of their first customers when I worked in our company's library (probably since 1995 or 1996) and used amazon.com for purchases as well as personal purchases.Going back to their offer... I used the links on the page where the offer was offered and put both in my shopping cart. Yes, it was my fault that it says it must be sold by amazon. I also thought I had updated the lens that came in the kit so the total price was correct. I came home, opened the package that was awaiting me, and started using the camera.I then looked at the receipt and realized I had the wrong kit lens -- and had been charged the full price for the second lens. I wrote amazon and was told I could return the camera if I had not opened it yet. Since I had opened the camera, I technically could not return it according to amazon and it would be a hassel to make the return and wait for the item again.So I decided that  I'm just not going to use amazon as  my main vendor any longer. I think their marketing was shoddy -- and if that's how they treat customers, I no longer have any loyalty. So I'm not saying I won't use amazon.com for future purchases, but I will only use them when their price beats their competitors. Yes, it will take me longer to make my purchases, and in the past I must admit that I didn't do competitive shopping if it was offered on amazon.com... I want to deal with companies that treat their customers well and don't try to trick them by having links to products that do not qualify for rebates. Yes, it was my fault, but I wonder how many others don't notice that statement or think if it's processed by amazon it is SOLD by amazon. My fault entirely but I want to trust the companies I deal with.As for the camera, it's fantastic thus far (but I've always been a point in shoot camera person so there's a learning curve). The lens in the offer is also powerful but again, I would check prices of competitors before I purchase from amazon again. One of my daughters has already given me some of the technical sites that compete with amazon.com so perhaps all of those high-priced purchases I've made in the past will be done through competitors in the future. It's been fun, amazon, but you have lost my loyalty for shoddy marketing.

Reviews.Title: Awesome starter DSLR, but AWB is disappointing..
Reviews.Author: Mike Patnode
Reviews.Content: As my first DSLR I'm quite pleased with this camera.  You can put the camera in full auto-mode and just point and shoot.  Being able to frame photos with a real zoom lens is a treat.  I strongly recommend the 18-135 kit just for that purpose.  The one thing that disappointed me was the auto-white-balance when turning off the flash.  One of the key reasons to go with an SLR is the high quality photos at high ISO speeds and not having to use a flash.  I was surprised how "orange" everything came out when I turned off the flash and still have yet to figure out how to adjust the white balance to compensate.  Two more features I wish this camera had:1. Ability to remove red-eye after taking the picture2. Ability to edit white balance after taking the picture.The LCD is very impressive and could easily be used for both these features.  Also, the video quality, even at 720p beats the 1080p of cheaper point-and-shoot cameras hands down.  So overall I'm quite happy with it, but be prepared to take the time for some research once you take it out of full-auto mode...

Reviews.Title: Shame on Canon, Shame on Amazon
Reviews.Author: Carlos Arroyave
Reviews.Content: First of all I want to apologize for my English, I hope I can make myself clear.I've been buying products from Amazon.com for more than 7 years, and I love their customer support and all what they have done for the market in this years, but selling a deffective product knowing it is deffective is ridiculous. It's been known since June that Canon has had problems with a certain lots easy to identify with the serial code. The simpler solution for canon and amazon was to just  place a Product Advisories at the botton of the short description telling you that you could get a bad product. I waited until August hoping the problem was solved, and the Advisories removed and I placed the order. Yesterday I received a white defective canon t4i, what a shame, the canon's solution is ask the buyers to send the camera and wait 3 weeks to be repaired. I am very disappointed on canon and Amazon, I never espected from these two big ones to throw their problems to the customer.Be careful and instead buy or keep your canon t3i or t2i or a NIKON.Update December 15th 2012:I gave 1 star at begining to alert people they could get a defective product, now that the problem has been solved I don't want to lower the average rate of the camera. Reviews.Title: Much less than I had expected...
Reviews.Author: Zachary Klein "Darkman"
Reviews.Content: It's possible i set my expectations too high, but after spending many many hours researching (reading reviews, comparing photos,  pixel peeping, reviewing specs, etc) I pulled the trigger on this with the 55-250mm lens combo deal, and all I can say is, I am slightly disappointed... I also own a Sony HX9V and Lumix FZ47K, so I'd been looking for a decent SLR to take that next step forward, and I just don't get what all the hype is about.First, let me say the build quality on the camera is excellent.  I love how it feels in my hands and I love when I'm able to snap off several shots quickly.  One thing I loved about my point and shoot was that I didn't need a viewfinder, and this camera is HORRIBLE to use UNLESS you use the viewfinder... If you try to use the rear digital display to snap a shot, it almost literally cripples the camera, as the shooting time requires several more seconds for it to focus and snap the picture... But I was ok with that, I have actually gotten used to using the viewfinder and started to prefer it over using the digital display... The touchscreen is a nifty feature and appears to work great.But considering this camera costs 2x what I spent on my HX9v, I expected much better image quality.  It feels like I could have saved myself $400+ and bought the HX20V and gotten relatively similar results, as I've played with it and it provided a marginal upgrade over the HX9V as far as image quality and speed.  And to be honest, that's all I've seen with the T4I camera so far is a marginal improvement.  I stepped outside today and snapped a handful of shots with each camera, and that quality wasn't much better, and speed was only 1-2 seconds apart for capturing and processing the image...Truth be told, I bought this camera hoping for better indoor / low light photos, and while this is a highly subjective issue, I just don't see the value per dollar here... This camera has issues focusing on things that are dark or black -- my TV for instance, a black LCD TV--this camera goes crazy and takes several seconds trying to figure out what it's looking at, and even then the photo is sub-par... I get the same issue with my dog, a black Labrador...The camera is simply confused by dark objects... I snapped several pictures of my office and many came out slightly blurred with bad white-balance issues, as things had a yellow tinge to them... I tried switching through several modes and got only slightly better results than I would get with the point & shoot.. I tried to point the camera to the sky to catch falling snowflakes, and the camera couldn't focus on that either...Maybe my expectations were too high?  Or it could be I'm lousy with the advanced camera.  If anything, this may be an indictment of the entry-level SLR cameras, as the point & shoots are quickly bridging that gap in quality and speed, and they cost a fraction of what this does..  Please don't get me wrong, there is difference in quality... But for anyone reading this and wanting to take the plunge,  don't expect a miracle here... I've snapped ~400-500 photos of various things and do see some improvement, but honestly, based on what I've seen so far, if I could go back in time I'd stop myself from making this purchase because I don't see a drastic improvement warranting the cost...Which, again, I want to say I'm not entirely negative on this camera... It feels great, shoots fast in general, and takes good pictures... Just don't expect the world from this camera and you'll be happy, which is why I'm rating it 3/5...* I will keep using the camera and play with the RAW images and change the review if needed...

Reviews.Title: just bought one
Reviews.Author: Tharuthalai Aasami "aasami"
Reviews.Content: I just bought one (June 15) from Best Buy but it has the 18 - 55 lens (from the old t3i) included in the kit. The new silent STM 18 - 135 mm lens will be included in the kit instead of the 18 - 55 and will be available in Best buy on June 26. I will get the new lens when it comes out and these timelines may apply to Amazon and other stores too. Here is my personal opinion and "non expert" 2 cents on this camera.Basically, I was looking for a user friendly instrument that can take good pictures in low light and indoors because with good lighting even point and shoots take excellent pics. Obviously any DSLR is going to better in this regard than a point and shoot. I do not expect a significant difference between a comparable Nikon or Sony or Canon DSLR irrespective of the spin  "experts" and companies may lay out for us. In terms of photograph quality, the t4i takes excellent pictures but do not expect a dramatic improvement. A lot of megapixels or autofocus points or more cross type sensors, or more bits in the processor or frames per second is not going to make a major difference unless you are taking pictures in special situations.In terms of video capability however, the t4i should be clearly superior to most comparable DSLRs in the same price category. According to sci tech today - the imaging chip in DSLRs is some 20 times larger than that found in a traditional camcorder. DSLR video is supposed to look sharper, more colorful and cinematic than footage shot on a camcorder. Documentaries shot on DSLRs are supposed to be close to movie quality and superior to camcorders. The new upgrades including continuous autofocus, silent lenses, touchscreen display, stereo mic and improved ISO due to the Digic 5 processor are all aimed at improving the video capabilities.I was waiting to buy a smaller less bulkier mirrorless micro four thirds camera but honestly, they are still not in the same league as DSLRs. After some thought, instead of waiting to find the ideal smaller camera I opted for the traditional DSLR with enhanced video capabilities. Overall, I think the upgrades make it more user friendly and is worth the extra $200.  Once I have the STM lenses, I will be able to evaluate the video capabilities better. I don't expect a perfect camera but I think this will fit my needs and I hope that I will not need to change the 5 stars I have given it now.

Reviews.Title: Not as good as T2i or T3i

I am not a professional, but do take a lot of pictures so do understand the adjustments needed. After using it for a few days and 600+ pictures later I decided to return it and go with the 60D. My unprofessional opinion is that it is the new Hybrid sensor, I beleive it is geared more for the video then stills. The cost is not much more then a T3i if not the same and just a 100 dollars plus a little bit for the 60D. I might have gotten a bad camera, but did not want to go through getting a replacement and if it was the same having to send it back as well. I only bought the body, so was using the same lens I was used to.

Reviews.Title: Open Your Eyes!
Reviews.Author: S. Normand "Scotcher"
Reviews.Content: It is easy to get tunnel vision with all these glowing reviews on Amazon.  However, this camera really doesn't have any standout features.  Its the same old technology that has been around for years.  You are still going to have to wait a ton of time between shots, the burst mode is slow, and the burst mode does not support focusing between shots.  The view finder is not going to actually show you the picture you are going to get since it is an optical viewfinder.  And the viewfinder is going to black out when you actually take the shot.  Sure, all these traditional SLR cameras take great pictures, but really, what camera at this price doesn't.  What are you really looking for at this price point?  For me, it is fast between shots and can burst fast so I am sure to get a great shot.  I hate cameras that make me wait between shots until the camera is ready to take another picture.If you want the hidden gem in the SLR camera world, check out the Sony SLT technology.  It is a new technology that is much faster and allows the viewfinder and focus mechanisms to function like they should.  I have the SLT-A57 and I think you can tell from the reviews that it is as good or better than any of these SLR cameras.No, I don't work for Sony.  I just think that someone should point out the fact that there are other options out there and better technology available.

Reviews.Title: A mind changed
Reviews.Author: William James Thomson
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for over 8 months now.I upgraded from a Nikon D3000.After working with DSLRs for over a year now, I was really excited to switch to one with so many more features compared to the D3000. I went back and forth between the D5200 and this, and I must say, I made the right choice.Initially, it was a rough road switching over. I had many new features I had to become comfortable with.I've taken over 10,000 photos with the T4i. The kit lens was terrible. Rarely did pictures come out in focus, even when using manual focus. The colors have never came out just right. No matter what I did, the colors always feel off.It took a lot of getting used to, I traded in the kit lens, bought some USM lenses, upgraded to Magic lantern, and now I'm getting some great photos.Looking back at the pictures I took with my Nikon, things were a lot easier then, but my photo taking abilities have really been taken to the next level with my Canon.It's a garbage camera for the price.Buyer beware.

Reviews.Title: Camera is well prosumer but careful with the lenses!
Reviews.Author: Ed in Raleigh
Reviews.Content: Writing about my Canon T4i experienceOkay, I finally understand why one should probably not deal with Amazon when it comes to big ticket items like cameras and lenses. True, you might save a few bucks in the short term, but in the long run the Amazon experience might cost you more!Less than 30 days ago I purchased from Amazon the T4i in kit form with 18-55mm EF-S IS II lens and a second lens that had promo pricing conditional on the camera purchase. I thought I had done my homework but it seems I failed to turn over a few rocks—enough to discover that although great for stills, the T4i requires special lenses to record videos. Non-STM lens recording with this camera sucks because of poor focusing of even slow moving objects. The STM lens issue is not readily apparent when you make a selection from Amazon’s EOS kit offerings.So, to make things right, I began a series of long phone calls to Amazon to try and work out a solution that included a swap of some kind. No two helpdesk technicians gave me exactly the same advice. Initially it was not going to be a problem for me to pack everything up and send it back at Amazon’s expense—they would even arrange to have UPS or USPS pick it up at my door. But when it came time to print the RMA for this, I discovered errors in which the language of the RMA did not match what I was returning, so I had to ignore that RMA.I initiated a new call, this time to the cameras specialists who initially assured me I could easily exchange the camera and lenses I’d purchased for the camera kit that included an STM lens. This path got stretched out over time and slowly went south as I was ultimately informed that this exchange could cost me “from 10% to 20% in restock fees.” That is to say this exchange could cost me $100 to $200 dollars out of picket.With that I resigned myself to my being stuck with the wrong lenses but at least having discovered a valuable lesson—that Amazon is not always the best way to go. My local Costco’s has a 90 day return policy on similar camera kits compared to Amazon’s rather misleading 30-day return policy. Amazon politely explains that if I send them my camera they must sell it as a used unit so I have to pay for the problem I created. To that, I ask who best to take a few buck loss, the little guy who has been a faithful Amazon customer or Amazon the multi-billion dollar corporation?My lesson learned (and my advice to you) when it comes to pricy electronics like cameras and lenses is to shop local where you have the freedom to exchange your purchasing mistakes and rediscover real customer service.

Reviews.Title: Received Recalled Camera 3 months after recall was announced
Reviews.Author: Tech-Guru
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera from Amazon in late August. Upon receipt, the case was already deteriorating...covered in a white grainy powder which has been identified as a hazard. The disappointing thing is that the camera is the subject of a federal recall and Amazon was notified of this quite a while back, yet continues to ship these defective cameras which are easily identifiable (I believe if the 6th digit of the serial number is a "1", it is part of the recall). I was really looking forward to this camera and I'm afraid to reorder one from Amazon, fearing another defective model and the problems and hassle that goes with shipping it back.8/22/2013 UPDATEI reordered the camera and was sent one that did not contain the defect. The camera performed well and I am upping my prior rating from 1 star to 4. I find that there is sometimes an apparition from the Canon lens when taking pictures with a strong central light-source (sunset) and the controls on the back of the camera are a little small, but other than those minor complaints I find this to be a reasonably good camera for the serious amateur and, given the recent price reductions, a fair value for the money.

Reviews.Title: Poor execution and service
Reviews.Author: K. M. Mbale "Collector of Stuff You Can't Tak...
Reviews.Content: No sooner had the camera arrived that Canon recalled it due to manufacturing defects. Canon promised the repair would take a couple of days at most. It has been over two weeks and counting that Canon has the camera. They cannot provide an estimated completion date for "changing the grips and handle." Since they have the camera, we cannot even return it for a different product. This purchase was meant to be a present; it has become an expensive disappointment. The product is well designed but Canon has let both service and quality slip to unacceptable levels.

Reviews.Title: Feature galore, unnecessarily complicated
Reviews.Author: Richard Lin
Reviews.Content: Just got this cameras a few days ago.  I went through the whole manual and did some shooting and printing today.  Unfortunately, I'll have to say this camera embodies what's wrong with many digital cameras today.  It's trying to do too much, which makes it much harder to use than necessary.  The manual is awful, as usual.The good points of the camera is that the body is small and light (compared to my 40D), and feels pretty good in my hand, and the LCD touch screen has good color and clarity, and very responsive.  The camera overall is pretty responsive if you only use the view finder.  This camera has touch screen focusing, but it's a joke.  It's so slow it's probably worse than most cheap point and shoot cameras.Image quality is what you would expect from Canon, reasonably good, but not great.  A casual photographer can probably do better by getting one of those m43 cameras such as Panasonic G5 or even GX1.

Reviews.Content: i wish i had a nice view of the t4i rebel, but i have this story.first t4i was in october 2012, looking real nice, fast shoting ,sharp images, very good quality on the pictures, it took a little time for me to discover i had a stuck pixel, some call it dead, hot... whatever, did all procedure on the manual cleaning, didnt work. Returning the second one and wait that other month without working.

Reviews.Title: T4i Slower to boot up
Reviews.Author: Gerry
Reviews.Content: Similar to T3i as expected- but power on from sleep mode is slower by a fraction of a second.  This is when the camera fell asleep and you press the shutter half way to wake it.  I found that the extra delay was annoying and caused me to miss some shots I wanted to take.  To put it another way, if they canged the design from Digic 4 to Digic 5, I would want it to be the same or faster- not slower.

Reviews.Title: very disappointed
Reviews.Author: MBO
Reviews.Content: Went on my first photo shoot with the my new camera and lens today --- I can't tell you how disappointed I am with the results.  Of the 200 images I shot maybe 10 are acceptable.  I'm a seasoned photographer so experimented with various modes - AV, TV, P, A+ and close up.  In all modes the focus is blurred, muddy, totally unacceptable.  A few of the images have one spot that holds focus, but most of the images have no point of focus - just a mass of blur.  Is it the camera body?  Is it the lens?  I don't know, but I'll be looking at returning it tomorrow.

Reviews.Title: Go for either T3i or 60D
Reviews.Author: Ty K
Reviews.Content: I bought T4i with 18-135 STM Lens last week. Fortunately, I didn't receive a lemon with respect to grip. This review is based on a quick use for a week.Image quality: Although there may be improvement in DIGIC 5 according to Canon AD, I could not tell much difference between DIGIC 4 and DIGIC 5.Low light performance: solid performance so far but I want to test more.Auto focus for video: As you can see in many reviews (search youtube), AF is working but fairly slow. Yes, STM works. I mean it is more silent zooming noise.5 frame speed: I haven't test seriously this function.Portability : No problem with body and 18-135 lens. To me, it's a main reason to choose this against 60D.Build quality: It looks same as T3i to me.Touch screen: It's convenient but not a "deal-maker".If you're mainly interested in taking photos, T3i is bang for the money and 60D would be better for photo and build quality. Overall, with this kind of high price tag, T4i looks like in a gray zone between T3i and 60D. That's why I gave only three stars.PS. I don't think this is only for product (function) review. We can complain anything about purchasing a product because it is vendor's website.

Reviews.Title: The Truth...Great Camera but I bought the SX50 HS...
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Hi Folks,I did buy this camera through Amazon. The only thing I hated about the camera was the lightness of it. When you pickup a lets say, Canon 60D...I figure this might be a good camera to compare weight. You will see a huge difference. The T4i just seems like nothing is inside the camera. It seems to me, in my opinion, if you ever dropped it by accident, the camera is done, throw it away. So, for a cheaper price, I bought the SX50 HS which is an amazing camera at a great price. Granted with the T4i you can change lens, get a battery grip etc..but at the end of the day, add up all the extras, for what? The SX50 HS will do just as good of job without spending upwards of a $1,000 for all the extras the T4i needs. About me, I own the 60D, D7000, EOS 5D Mark III, and the EOS-1D X. I use the SX50 for everyday use. Again, you really need to go into a camera shop and feel the T4i..and then compare it to the 60D, a heavier camera to see what I am talking about. This is the reason I say, for the price, the SX50 HS will do just as good a job at a cheaper cost to own price! Cheers...! P.S. also...the SX50 HS shoots at around 13 fps compared to the T4i at around 5 fps.

Reviews.Title: Order Cancelled By Amazon
Reviews.Author: Ida Know
Reviews.Content: I placed an order for this camera on June 10th when the seller was Amazon and the item was listed as "in stock."  At the time, the price was $899 and there was a 4% off promotional offer.  My shipping date was pushed back several times.  The story I got from Amazon was that while the website said the item was in stock, when they went to fill the order they found that in fact it was not on the shelves. Reviews.Title: So far, I'm disappointed in this camera
Reviews.Author: Karen  Wilhelm
Reviews.Content: I received this camera a short time ago and so far, I'm not impressed with it.  I just checked out the photos I took over Christmas and found most of them are not in focus and the exposure isn't very good either! (Not being familiar with the camera, I left it in auto everything mode.)  I took the camera to our Christmas light parade and was so disappointed, I was looking forward to getting some cool shots of the floats.  The camera refused to auto focus if I zoomed in at all and didn't do all that well when zoomed all the way out. (I wasn't aware at that time that I could have focused manually.)  It just doesn't like low light and that seems to include all shots indoors.  I've also found that the depth of field is very, very narrow when the camera is set in the auto mode. I was playing with a christmas decoration and found that just a couple inches made the difference between in focus and out of focus.  I need to take some time to read the manual and see if I can improve things using manual modes.  My eyesight is poor and had I known what a hard time it would have using auto focus, I wouldn't have gotten the camera!  I loved my little worn out Sony that this is replacing and am wishing I hadn't spent my money going with a DSLR!I got a second lens with the camera, an efs 55-250 zoom.  I have only had it on the camera once for a short try, it drove me crazy with the auto focus going in and out, it would not focus at all!I just got a notice from Canon that my camera has the defective rubber grips!  I thought by now all of them would have been sold or recalled!!  So now, I have to send the camera off to be repaired!  I'm upset with Amazon for shipping me one after all this time, they should have all been recalled!!  Had the notice still been posted on Amazon, I wouldn't have purchased this camera!Update on my T4i:I contacted Amazon about the Canon recall of my camera and bless their heart, they replaced it immediately with a new one!  Amazon rocks!  Unfortunately, the replacement camera had a problem.  The flash didn't work on it and I should have taken it up with Amazon again!  I contacted Canon and was told to send the camera in for repair.  Cost me $28.05 to send it in, which cost Canon won't reimburse me! I'm not happy with Canon right now, they send out a defective camera and I pay for it!! And I get back a camera that may or may not be fixed! Wishing right now I'd bought a Nikon!Update on my T4i:I've had the camera for 6 months now and am getting used to it.  They did fix the flash problem and it's worked okay since.  I have had some trouble with the camera freezing up on me, it won't respond to anything, it won't even shut down!  The only way I can get it to work again is to remove the battery and put it back in.  Not too happy with that!  I have been using it more in manual mode and it seems to freeze up in manual mode more than it was in the auto modes.  But, it shouldn't freeze up at all!  Still disappointed in the quality of this camera overall.

Reviews.Title: Consider the Sony DSC-RX100 20.2 MP Exmor CMOS
Reviews.Author: review
Reviews.Content: This is a review I probably would've liked to have read before making a purchase for this Canon DSLR.1) The basic kit lens, 18-55mm, is bad for video taking because of the mechanical sounds the lens auto-focus makes that gets recorded into the video. The alternative solution is to get the STM lens, but that lens is a lot longer (because of the zoom) and less portable.2) The next best lens is an ultrasonic lens made by canon, which is acceptably quieter, but will cost around $750. For video taking, the auto-focus adjustments may be a bit jerky because the fast focusing feature of USM will adjust constantly as you move from object to object.3) The ultrasonic lens line-up options comes in a lot of variety, but there are always trade-offs. For example, to get this camera to work well in bright and low light, you need a zoom lens and a low-light lens w/ 1.8F (the lower the number the better it works at night). So to shoot well in day and night, you need two lens, costing around $750 per.4) It would cost you around $800 for the camera, $750 for a good zoom lens, and another $750 for a low light lens.5) Why pay that much when you can get a pocket-sized DSLR image quality lens with an 1.8F zoom lens for only $650 in a Sony DSC-RX100 20.2 MP Exmor CMOS? That camera is portable and small enough to not lug around. You can buy that model and the next 2 generations of that model for what it would cost to buy this Canon DSLR and the lens features to match the functionality of that Sony model.

Reviews.Title: Just like the T2i?
Reviews.Author: Capt. Video
Reviews.Content: REVISED, REVISED REVIEWAfter slamming the T2i lover, I received some partially appropriate criticism for doing that about which I was complaining: reviewing without using. Actually I was reviewing a review but that makes me guilty of taking up space and giving five * without any helpful information about the product.  Mea culpa.I have now purchased the product in question.  I have had only about an hour to fiddle with it before sending it off on a trip with the wife.  But as far as I'm concerned (and T2i guy proves, if nothing else, that this is a personal assessment that depends upon experience, financial resources, uses for the camera, etc.) an hour is all I needed to say: it's worth the price of admission. The touch/variable angle screen alone is a significant improvement.  Giving video its own position on the power switch reveals an underlying greater respect for that aspect of the unit.  Compared to the improvements from T2 to T3, this is a quantum leap before we get to what's inside. I've reduced to **** because my brief time with the camera left me with some doubts about the video auto focus and how supposedly quiet are the new IS lenses. But I can tell you with no reluctance, this ain't no T2i.MY BADDER than I was.  Being an amateur in the still arena (a little bit wiser re video that I've been involved with since we relied on Kodak 7242) I thought I was buying the new, quieter lens with my T4i or, owning lenses from my lost T2i, the wife's 50D, and my Sony Camcorder (FS100) I would have just bought the camera.  Thus the noise is explained.  I know nothing about the new lenses. I regret, as they say in Washington, that I misspoke.My wife has returned the T4i with which I will now have a chance to play.  But, just in case this is the end of line (or blog) for me, even before touching it again, I say again, this is a very cool camera and quite a leap from the T2/T3 era. Assuming the new lenses are as good as the T4i, I raise my rating to 5*. Is the "leap" worth the bucks? Ahhh...that is the Shakespeare and everyone interprets The Bard a little differently, right?

Reviews.Title: Brian R
Reviews.Author: Brian Rowe
Reviews.Content: OK I usually don't review products I don't own anywhere on the internet but I noticed a 1 star rating and I thought I'd have to balance it out with my completely speculative review. I want to make it clear that I don't own this camera and haven't used it. I've been following Canon DSLR prices and releases quite closely, as I'm in the market for a camera.It seems quite a bit premature to rate a product with 1 star which you don't own, haven't used or even held, and haven't taken the time to research.This camera is supposed to add a lot of features from what I've seen/heard/read.1. Touch Screen - I haven't seen this on any other DSLR and it definitely wasn't on the T3i. Touch screens are how people have come to expect to interact with electronics. People who want Hi-end electronics think having to press multiple buttons at the same time and turn dials is complicated and antiquated. Even if it is time-tested and efficient once you're used to it. For someone entering the DSLR, and shooting something other than Automatic I see a touch screen as a great learning interface.2. Continuous Video AF and face tracking is another new feature aimed at point and shooters. The video quality of this camera will be much the same as the T3i but will allow new users (and users that haven't had good results with the T3i) to keep moving subjects in focus will taking video. Entry level users aren't going to spend enough time to perfect of the craft of manual focusing, nor do they want to buy an expensive rig with focus-wheels and such to film their kid's soccer match.3. It works with a new group of STM lenses Canon will be releasing.4. New Digic 5 processor which allows for 5 fps in continuous mode over the T3i's 3.7.Canon knew what they were doing when designing this camera: Bringing  point and shoot features into an already successful Entry-Level DSLR. By doing so they will probably also pull a bunch of users already paying $600+ on hi-end point and shoots into the the DSLR fold. This means they'll have people buying more accessories and lenses. A smart business move.To address any concerns about bugs, most all software problems should be fixable with Firmware updates and any hardware problems will be covered within the 1 year warranty if bought on Amazon or any other Authorized Canon Dealer. These are things any early adopters should be willing to do when buying a brand new product.All-in-all I'd have to say this camera is with the $100 price jump, IF it's overall feature set fits your needs. If you've been considering the T3i, wait one more pay check and get this. Waiting months for the price to go down is one theory but that's going to be months worth of great photos and videos you're not documenting. Photographers capture light to show their take on brief moments. How many are you gonna miss waiting for a $100 price drop. Look at the difference in features between the 2 cameras be low this. Look at the difference in the 2 cameras above

Reviews.Title: Not what many think it will be - just WAIT
Reviews.Author: Edward V. Byrne
Reviews.Content: I've read with interest the reviews on the T4i.  It's curious that a product few reviewers (including me) have ever laid hands on is evoking such intense feelings and commentary.That being said, I like the T4i "on paper."  I hope it proves to be a good step up in the Rebel line when it's finally delivered and evaluated in detail by the many pro review sites.But there are major concerns, which few are talking about on this page.  They are these:There's a myth that one of the reasons the T4i is SO dramatically better than its Rebel predecessors is because it has a faster burst rate (5 fps compared to 3.7 fps for the T3i). But that stat is deceptive and highly misleading. In fact, both cameras have exactly the same buffer (internal memory) capacity for RAW images (6), while the T3i has a superior buffer capacity for .jpegs (34 compared to 30 for the new T4i). The buffer data on both, by the way, has been widely reported by at least two professional reviewers on different websites. The bottom line is that for all practical purposes, the cameras will capture images at virtually the same speed, although the T3i may be slightly better with .jpegs. Buffer size is what counts, not burst rate (and the Canon 60D is better than both in that department).And there's a larger issue. The real reason most people will make the decision to purchase this camera is because of video auto-focus, and the new lenses which are designed to work especially with that function. Read any favorable review of the T4i and you'll see that's the main topic of interest with everybody. But one reviewer within the past few days who DOES OWN the camera said the video auto-focus system is a mess, unless you've got a completely still object (and if you do, for what do you need the auto-focus feature?). That hands-on reviewer, by the way, wrote: "The T4i did a lot of hunting around trying to get good focus so if you plan on chasing a 2 year old while recording good luck! I will say that I used a regular photo lens and not an STM lens, but I just can't see see how the focusing can keep up with moving objects other than snails or turtles! It is still too new a technology and I'm sure the T5i will be much better at it."A professional videographer with news journalism experience -- and who loves Rebel cameras, by the way, especially the T3i -- recently encouraged his readers to think carefully before "upgrading" to the T4i. He described the video auto-focus as a "deal breaker" for him, since he always turns off that feature, even when using a dedicated video cam. He noted that HE wants to make the decision when to shift focus, rather than have the camera do it for him every time he moves it a few inches one way or another, or every time the subject moves slightly. It makes very good sense, if you think about it. He says here's why NOT to jump for the T4i: [...].The bottom line is that both an amateur with actual T4i experience and a pro videographer believe that the video auto-focus component of the camera will be a negative, not a positive, for most users.It makes sense to wait for further MAJOR improvements which will appear on the T5i. And it makes even better sense to wait for the next upgrade to the Canon 60D, which cannot be far off given the advanced age of the 60D. The next generation of that camera (60D) likely will cost only slightly more than the T4i, and will leave many purchasers of the latter with buyer's remorse.

With video ability, you really need a lot of memory, and large capacity SD cards are much cheaper than CF cards. It feels solid (maybe not as solid as 50D, but much lighter), and photos seemed to be pretty good (I didn't do any side to side comparisons, just eye test) as well. Canon 17-55 and sigma 24-70 lenses seemed to be large and disproportionate, but sigma 18-250 seemed pretty good on it. Now I am actually considering very seriously to buy one for myself - relatively small size and video ability makes it great during travel (even small size difference matters, after 2 weeks of dragging my 50d - the great camera, I love it! - in Europe).
